Steering Gear, Main: It is the main means of applying torque to the rudder stock (e.g. tiller or quadrant) necessary for effecting movement of the rudder for the purpose of steering the watercraft under normal service conditions.

Steering Gear Control System, Remote: It is the means by which the required rudder movements are • controlled remotely from the navigating bridge to the steering gear power unit controls.


9.1.1.4 Classification of Watercraft. Watercrafts are classified as liners or carriers, according to type, purpose and service, and place of operation as for international, short international, coastwise, bay and lake or river-sea operations. These include the following:

(A) Passenger ship or ferry boat, hydrofoil or hovercraft;

(B) Cargo vessel (as bulk, log or timber, ore or metal, coal, grain, cement in bags, :flour, reefer, mobile vehicle, live animals, general cargo, as container van or multi­ purpose cargo carriers). Roll-on/Roll-off vessels;

(C) Vessel for carriage of all classes of dangerous cargoes;

(D) Tank.ship (Tanker or Supertanker) (Oil, gasoline, liquefied or compressed gases, chemicals in liquid, solid or substance forms);

(E) Yacht for pleasure use;

(F) Expoship and watercraft for amusement and display purposes;

(G) Fishing boat (for trawling, fishing, freezing, canning and processing);

(H) Vessel/barge for salvaging, dredging, pile-driving;

(I) Watercraft forcable-laying or pipe-laying operations;

(J) Floating power plant barge;

(K) Training or hospital ship;

(L) Tugboat or pusher boat, workboat or supply boat;

(M) Fireboat for firefighting;

(N) Floating tourist hotel, restaurant or casino;

(0) Watercraft for pollution control;

(P) Watercraft for geodetic and ocean research;

(Q) Search and rescue vessels;

(R) Naval and coast guard vessels;

(S) Motor launches for pilotage use;

(T) Patrol boat or speed boat;

(U) Mobile offshore oil drilling rig/production platform and habitat;

(V) Survey and exploration ship.

9.1.2 Electrical Plans and Specifications

9.1.2.1 General. Electrical plans and specifications shall be prepared in accordance with the provisions of this article, in addition to applicable provisions of Article 1.3.

9.1.2.2 Application. Electrical plans and specifications shall apply to new, existing, additional, and remodeling installations, including those of watercrafts of foreign construction acquired for Philippine Ownership.

9.1.2.3 Plan Requirements.

(A) Title Block or Nameplate. ln addition to the

requirements of Section 1.3.2.2 it shall show:

(1) Name and identification number of watercraft.

(2) Type of service operation.

(B) Equipment Layout. Layout plans shall show the location/arrangement of the following electrical machineries and equipment on profile and deck plans, drawn to scale:

(1) Main and emergency generators,

(2) Accumulator batteries,

(3) Transformers, power rectifiers and inverters,

(D) Wiring Plan. Wiring drawings on profile and deck plans, drawn to scale shall include the following:

(1) Power Circuits.

a. Generator, main and emergency,

b. Accumulator batteries,

c. Switchboards and metering instrument,

d. Circuit breakers/fuses, and

e. Motors and control devices.

(2) Lighting and Receptacle Circuits.

11. Lighting and receptacle outlets for main and emergency systems,

b. Lighting fixtures: location, type, and rating, and

c. Complete feeder list and branch circuit load with voltage drop for longest run of each size cable. Size of wire, if other than 2.0 rnm2 stranded and size of raceway if other than 13 mm (16mm) nominal diameter of conduit; the number of wires in each raceway by the corresponding number of crossbars.

(3) Navigation and Communications Circuits.

(4) Switchboards, panelboards,

distribution panels, and

a. Navigation (running) light, and navigation indicator panel,

(5) Electrical propulsion machineries,

(6) Motors,

(7) Steering gear machineries,

(8) Lighting fixtures,

(9) Navigation (running) lights and navigational instruments, and

(10) Signaling and communications equipment.

(C) Schematic or One Line Diagram. Schematic or one line diagrams shall be for the following:

(1) Main generator supply,

(2) Emergency power,

(3) Electric propulsion,

(4) Steering gear,

(5) Navigational lights,

(6) Fire protection,

(7) Ground protection,

(8) Shore power supply, and

(9) Survival crafts.

b. Navigation equipment, such as marine radar, marine sonar, marine loran, echo-sounder, marine global positioning system (gps) navigator, gyro compass/standard magnetic compass, doppler log, and color video sounder,

c. General alarm, fire alarm and emergency alann systems,

d. Signaling and monitoring systems,

e. Electronic and communications equipment, such as radio, television; video, telephone, engine order telegraph, call bells, and

f. Rudder angle, propeller pitch and shaft speed indicators.

(4) Instrumentation and Control Circuits.

a. Generators and synchronizing devices,

b. Accumulator batteries,

c. Motors and controls,

d. Propulsion system,

e. Steering gear system,

ARTICLE 9.1 - GENER.AL CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS

f. Watertight doors, electrically actuated,

g. Ventilating system,

h. Inert gas system,

i. Cathodic electrode protection, and

j. Refrigerated cargo space.

(E) Design Computations. Design computations or design analyses shall be included on the plans/drawings or maybe submitted on separate sheets of uniform size paper.

(F) Schedule of Loads. Schedule of loads in tabulated form of power, lighting, and other loads of normal operating loads on the system, estimated for the different operating conditions expected for main and emergency systems.

(G) Legend. Refer to Appendix A - Electrical Symbols.

9.1.2.4 Specifications and Data Requirements. Sp�cifications or data written on the plans/drawings shall be submitted on uniform size paper shall cover the following:

(A) Propulsion Machinery, Main and Emergency Generators, and Vital Motors 100 kW and Over. Complete ratings and class of insulation.

(B) Main and Emergency Generators, and Vital Motors Below 100 kW Rating. Complete ratings, class of insulation and type of enclosure.

(C) Motor Control Equipment. Type of controls, type of enclosure, running overcurrent protection, contactor standard size or rating.

(D) Short Circuit Data. In order to establish that the protective devices on the main switchboard have a sufficient short circuit interrupting capacity, data shall be submitted giving the maximum calculated short­ circuit current available at the main busbars. Similar calculations shall be made on the other points in the distribution systems where necessary to detennine the adequacy of the interrupting capacities of protective devices.

(E) Cable Grouping. Data or plan indicating the criteria to be followed on the cable grouping (e.g. segregation on the cable tray by type, size and voltage rating, and cable banking). (See Section 3.62.1.5).

(F) Special Equipment. Indicating ratings, and classification of service, or duty cycle of:

(1) Transformers,

(2) Inverters,

(3) Rectifiers,

(4) Heaters,

(5) X-ray apparatus,

(6) Electric welding equipment, and

(7) Others.


9.1.2.5 Other Details. The following details shall be prepared in addition to those required in Section 1J. 2.3.

(A) Hazardous Zones and Spuces. An arrangement plan showing the location of electrical equipment in these areas, indicating:

(1) Type of equipment;

(2) Type of protection;

(3) Temperature rise;

(4) Certifying authority.

(5) Certificate number; and

(6) Installation instruction, and certification agency restriction for intrinsically safe systems.

(B) Low Energy Power and Low Voltage Power Installations. Low energy powers and low voltage power installation showing:

(1) Details of battery installation and/or other source of low voltage or low energy power;

(2) Equipment, wiring, actuating mechanism and preventive devices; and

(3) Ventilation details of battery room.

(C) Lightning Protection System.

(D) Drawing. Typical drawing of standard practices and details of:

(1) Cable supports and sealing;

(2) Cable stuffing tubes as pipe sleeves and packing glands;

(3) Cable splicing;

(4) Bulkhead and deck penetration; and

(5) Watertight and explosion proof connections to equipment.

(E) Grounding Systems.


9.1.2.6 Additional and Remodeling Plans. Layout and wiring plans for additions, or remodeling shall be submitted to the government agency having jurisdiction. No addition, temporary or permanent, shall be connected to the approved load of an existing

installation until it has been ascertained that the current carrying capacity and the conditions of the existing accessories, conductors, switchgears and generation plant are adequate.

9.1.3 Requirements for Electrical Installation

9.1.3.1 Approval Required. The conductors, wiring methods and equipment required by this Code shall be acceptable only when approved.

9.1.3.2 Other Requirements. Conductors and equipment for installation shall comply with the provisions of Article 1.10 in addition to the general and special requirements provided in this Chapter.


9.1.4 General Requirements


9.1.4.1 Equipment Location. Electrical equipment shall be so placed or protected as to minimize the probability of mechanical injury or damage from the accumulation of dust, oil vapor, steam or dripping liquids.

Apparatus liable to arcing shall be ventilated or placed in ventilated compartments in which flammable gases, acid fumes and oil vapors cannot accumulate.

Skylights and ventilators shall be so arranged as to avoid the probability of flooding the apparatus.


9.1.4.2 Protection from Bilge Water. All generators, motors and electric couplings shall be so arranged that they cannot be damaged by bilge water, and, if necessary, a watertight coaming shall be provided to form a well around the base of such equipment with provision for removing the water from the well. Where electric power is used for propulsion, the equipment shall be so arranged that it will operate satisfactorily in the event of partial flooding of bilge water above the tank top up to the floor plate level.


9.1.4.3 Accessibility. The design and arrangement of electrical equipment is to provide accessibility to parts requiring inspection or adjushnents. Armature and field coils, rotors and revolving fields shall be removable and where air ducts are used, there shall be means of access.


9.1.4.4 Watertight Equipment. All electrical equipment exposed to the weather or located in spaces where it would be exposed to sea splashing or other severe moisture conditions, shall be of the watertight type or be protected by means of watertight enclosures, which shall be such as to prevent the exposure of the equipment to temperatures in excess of that for which they have been designed.

9.1.4.5 Materials. In general, all electrical equipment shall be constructed of durable and flame retardant materials. Materials shall be resistant to con-osion, moisture, high and low temperatures, and shall have qualities necessary to prevent deterioration in the ambient conditions the equipment may be expected to encounter.


9.1.4.6 Lubricating System. Lubricating system shall not be adversely affected by vibration and shock which in normal or,cration, and with the watercrnft inclined from the nmmal at any angle up lo 15 degrees tnmsversely and 10 degrees longitudinally, and when rolling up to 22.5 degrees from the vertical.


9.1.4.7 Equipment and Cables Locations from Magnetic Compass. Electrical equipment and cables shall be so placed at such a distance from the magnetic compasses or shall be so screened that the interfering external magnetic field is negligible, even when circuits arc switched ON and OFF.


9.1.4.8 Electrical Hardware. Nuts, screws, bolts, pins, and the like used in connection with current carrying parts and working parts shall be effectively tight and mechanically locked to prevent loosening.


9.1.4.9 insulating Materials and Insulated Winding. Insulating materials and insulated windings shall be resistant to moisture, sea air, oil vapor, and fungus.


9.1.4.10 Hazardous Locations, Installations and Equipment.

(A) Electrical Equipment. Electrical equipment m hazardous locations shall be of a type suitable for such locations.

(B) Cables. Cables in hazardous locations shall be armored or mineral-insulated metal-sheathed and when passing through boundaries of such locations, they shall be run through gastight fittings.

(C) Lighting Circuits. Lighting circuits in hazardous spaces shall be conttolled by double-pole switches located outside such spaces.


9.1.4.11 Reference Ambient Temperature.

{A) Watercrafts for Unrestricted Service, and for Navigating in Philippine Waters.

(B) Watercrafts for Restricted Service. Watercrafts intended solely for operation in northern or southern waters outside the tropical belt.

ARTICLE 9.1 - GENERAL CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS

9.1.4.12 Prccimtions Against Shock, Fire, and Other Hazards of Electrical Origin.

(A) Passenger Ships and Cargo Ships.

Reference Ambient Temperature (''C)

(1) Primary cooling water supply 30

(2) All equipment located in machinery spaces 45

(engine room, boiler room and the like) and on weather decks

(3) All equipment located in all olher spaces 40

Exception: For rotating machines located in 50

(2) above

(1) Exposed Metal Parts and Frames. All exposed metal parts of dectrical machines or equipment which are not intended to b c energized but

Reference Ambient Temperature (0C)

(1) Primary cooling water supply 25

(2) All equipment located in all other spaces 40

Exception: For rotating machines located in 45

machinery spaces and/or weather decks

are liable to become energized under fault conditions, shall be grounded; and all electrical apparatus shall be so constructed and so installed that danger of injury in ordinary handling shall not exist.

Metal frames of all portable electric lamps, tools and similar apparatus, supplied as ship's equipment shall be grounded through 8 suitable conductor, unless equivalent provisions are made such as by double insulation or by an isolating transformer.

(2) Main and Emergency Switchboard. Main and emergency switchboards shall be totally enclosed so arranged as to give easy access at back and front, without danger to personnel. The sides and backs and, where necessaiy the fronts shall be suitably guarded. Exposed current carrying parts at voltage to ground exceeding safe voltage shall not be installed on the face of any switchboard or control panel.

(3) Hull Return. Where the hull return system of distribution is used, special precautions shall be made and approved. Hull return shall not be used in tankcrs/tankship/supertankers.

(4) Cables. All metal sheaths and armor of cables shall be electrically and mechanically continuous

and shall be grounded. Where the cables arc neither sheathed nor armored and there might be a risk of fire in the event of an electrical fault, precautions shall be made to prevent fire.

(5) Lighting Fittings. Lighting littings shall be

,manged to prevent temperatures that would be injurious to the wiring, and to prevent surrounding materials from becoming excessively hot.

(6) Wiring. Wiring shall be supported in such a manner as to avoid chafing or other injury. Each separate circuit shall be protected against short­ circuit and overload.

(7) Accumulator Batteries. Accumulator batteries shall be secured in place and suitably housed. The compartments shall be properly constructed and adequately ventilated.

(8) Communication Wiring System. Wiring for interior communication essential for safety and for emergency a\ann and fire detection shall be so arranged as to avoid galleys, machinery spaces and other enclosed spaces having high risk of fire except those necessary to provide communication or to give alarm within these spaces or to detect fire occurrences.

(8) Passenger Ships Only.

(1) Distribution System. Distribution system shall be so arranged that fire in any fire zone will not interfere with essential services in any other fire zone.

(2) Cables. Electric cables shall be of a flame­ retarding type/fire-resisting type.

(3) Hazardous Spaces. In spaces where flammable mixtures are liable to collect, no eleclrical equipment shall be installed unless it is of a type, which will not ignite the mixture concerned, such as flameproof or explosion proof or intrinsically­ safe equipment.

(4) Lighting Circuit. Lighting circuit in a bunker or hold shall be provided with an isolating switch outside the space.

(5) Jointi,. Joints in all conductors except for low voltage communications circuits shall be made only in junction or outlet boxes. All such boxes or wiring devices shall be so constructed as to prevent the spread of the fire from the box or device. Where splicing is employed it shall only be by an approved method such that it retains the original mechanical and electrical properties of the cable.

(6) Wiring Systems. Wiring for interior communications essential for safety and for emergency alarm systems shall be arranged to avoid galleys, machinery spaces and other enclosed spaces having a high risk of fire except those necessary to provide communication or to give alann within those spaces.

(C) Cargo Ships Only. Devices liable toarcing shall not be installed in any compartment assigned principally to accumulator batteries unless the devices are flameproof or explosion proof.

ARTICLE 9.2 - SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN LOCATIONS AND SYSTEMS

9.2.1 Locations

9.2.1.1 Hospital or Dispens11ry Spaces Certified for Use on Watercrafts. The electrical installation and electrical equipment in anesthetizing locations and in storage spaces for combustible anesthetic or disinfecting agents shall be approved types for use in Class 1, Group C hazardous locations.

9.2.1.2 Locations Where Gasoline or Other Highly Volatile Motor Fuel is Stowed.

(A) Equipment Installed Within 460 Millimeters Above the Deck. Equipment such as cutouts, switches, convenience outlets, lampholders, generators and motors, or other electrical equipment having make-or­ break or sliding contacts, when installed within 460 mm above the deck, shall be of type approved for Class I, Group C hazardous locations.

(B) Equipment Installed at or Over 460 Millimeters Above the Deck. Electrical equipment installed at or over 460 mm above the deck shall be of the totally enclosed type.

9.2.1.3 Submersible Motor-Driven Bilge Pumps.

(A) Installation. The electric motor driving the submersible bilge pump shall be installed in an open end air-bell such that flooding of the compartment in which it is located to the bulkhead deck will not cause the water to enter the motor. The motor may be outside of the open end air-bell provided it is protected against splashing water from the bottom. Cables to the motor shall enter through the open bottom of the air-bell.

(B) Continuous Operation. The motor shall be capable of continuous operation at rated load under normal and emergency conditions.

(C) Location. The motor controller shall be located above the bulkhead deck.

(D) Master Switch. The master switch at the motor shall be connected so that it could be completely disconnected from the circuit when the motor is started or stopped from the remote master switch.

9.2.2 Auxiliary Systems

9.2.2.1 Electrically Operated Watertight Door System.

(A) Power Supply. Electrically operated watertight door shall be supplied by the emergency power system if the main power source becomes inoperative.

(B) Cables. All cables used in connection with the watertight door system shall be either lead sheathed and armored, impervious sheathed and armored, or mineral­ insulated metal sheathed.


9.2.2.2 Fire-Screen Door Holding and Release Systems.

(A) Fire-Screen Door Holding and Release Mechanism. The fire-screen door holding and release mechanism shall consist of an electromagnet with a self-aligning armature plate on each door to be seized and held by the electromagnet when the fire-screen door is fully open; a control switch located adjacent to the door to interrupt the current to tW electromagnet; and a central control in the wheel-house or fire control room to intemipt remotely the current to all holding magnets.

(B) Fire-Screen Door Holding Circuit. The fire­ screen door holding circuit shall he so arranged that loss of potential from any cause will release the doors, except that momentary interruptions of the circuit that may result from the operation of automatic bus-transfer devices in connection with the emergency lighting and power system, will not release the doors.

(C) Central Control Station and Local Control Switch. The central control station and local control switch shall each consist of an enclosed externally operable fused switch, circuit breaker, or magnetic contactor of suitable rating.

(D) Simultaneous Release. Where several doors are in close proximity to each other, a single local control station switch of suitable rating may be used to release them simultaneously.

(E) Electrical Supply Arrangement. When the arrangement of the electrical supply involves transfer relays to connect the supply from a normal to a temporary source, a door-holding electromagnet shall be the armature so that, with a pull on the armature of 50 kilograms, the armature will be held in the closed position for approximately 0.25 second after the circuit

to the electromagnet is op_ened. The electromagnet shall be designed for continuous duty in an ambient air temperature of 50°C with a temperature rise ofnot more than 55°C for Class A insulation nor more than 75°C for Class B insulation. The magnet enclosure shall be either dripproof or watertight.

(F) Power Supply. The source of power for the fire­ screen door holding and release system shall be from the main and emergency power systems.

(G) Subdivided Circuits. On large watercrafts where simultaneous closing of all fire-screen doors will interfere with the fire-fighting operations, the fire­ screen door release system shall be subdivided into

i several circuits so that it will be possible to isolate any compartment in which a fire is registered.


9.2.2.3 Electric Motor for Lifeboat Handling.

(A) Waterproof. Electric motors installed m conjunction with lifeboat handling shall be of waterproof construction subject to the spray-tight test. Before conducting this test, all joints painted or having gaskets or sealing compounds, shall be broken and reassembled three (3) times.

(B) Enclosure Test Methods. Each enclosure for motor controller and switching device, when installed in locations exposed to the weather, shall be subjected to one of the following methods of submergence for a period of five (5) continuous minutes for water leakage.

!

r Method 1. The enclosure shall be submerged in water to a depth so that the highest point of the enclosure in its nonnally mounted position is under water of 900 mm head, or

Method 2. The enclosure shall be submerged in water to a depth at least 75 mm at the highest point in an open

9.2.2.4 Wiring of Lifeboat Winch Components.

(A) Main Linc Emergency Switch, When the motor controller of a lifeboat winch power unit is located adjacent to the winch, the main line emergency switch shall disconnect all parts of the lifeboat power urrit, including the motor controller and limit switches, from all sources of potential.

(B) Switch Disconnect. When th.e motor controller of a lifeboat winch power unit is remotely located with relation to the winch, a switch shall be provided at the controller arranged to disconnect the entire winch electrical installation from all sources of potential.

(C) Davit Arm Limit Switches. Davit arm limit switches, whether connected in the power circuit or in the control circuit, shall disconnect all ungrounded conductors of the circuit controlled. These switches shall be arranged to stop the travel of the davit arms not less than 300 mm from their final stowed position and they shall remain open until the davit arms move outboard beyond the tripping position of the switches.

(D) Main Line Emergency, Clutch Interlock, and Master Switches. When one motor is used with two winches, a main line emergency switch; a clutch interlock switch, and a master switch shall be provided for each winch. The main line emergency switch shall be connected in series ahead of the motor controller. The master switches shall be connected in parallel and each in series with the corresponding clutch interlock switch for that winch. The clutch interlock switches shall open the circuit to its master switch except when the power unit is clutched to the associated winch. Means shall be provided to prevent the power unit operating both winches simultaneously.

(E) Power Disconnecting Means. Where power-driven winches are used, satisfactory means shall be provided

I tattle Sufficient vacuum shall then be applied to the

to disconnect power to the winch before a hand crank

inside of the enclosure to produce an external pressure equivalent to 900 mm head of water.

(C) Additional Test. The additional test sball be conducted immediately after completion of either of the above test methods and while the enclosure is still submerged, an internal air pressure shall be applied for a period of.five (5) minutes equal to 1056 kilograms per square meter, plus a pressure equivalent to the depth of submergence.

(D) Enclosure Considered Sptaytight. Under these test, the enclosure will be considered spraytigbt if no water is found inside the encl9sure, and if no air bubbles are seen to.emerge. Where a shaft enters th� enclosure, the shaft shall be operated twice while subID�rged.

can be engaged with the winch operating shaft and this interruption of power shall be maintained while the hand crank is so engaged.

(F) Location. The main line emergency disconnect

• switch shall be so located as to be:

(1) Adjacent to the master switch;

(2) Within reach of the winch switch;

(3) In a position accessible to the person in-charge of the boat stowage; and

(4) In a position from which the movement of both davit anns can be observed as they approach the final stowed position.

9.2.2.5 Electric Heater.

(A) Risk of Fire. Electric heaters shall be soconstructed, installed and protected that clothing, bedding and other flammable materials cannot come in contact with flame in such a way to cause risk of fire.

(B) Heating by Convection. Cabin electric heaters shall be designed to heat surrounding air principally by convection. Heater elements shall be of the enclosed type, the element case or jacket to be of a corrosion­ resistant material.

(C) Overheating Protection, Heaters shall be provided with a suitable regulating switch having a thermal cutout of the manually-reset type that will prevent overheating. The external ,temperature of the heater enclosing case shall not exceed a temperature of 125°C, except that the external temperature of the enclosure of flush-mounted heaters shall not exceed a temperature.of 100°C.

(D) Maximum Temper-ature of Deck or Bulkhead Surface. When heaters are mounted upon, or adjacent to, the deck of bulkhead, the construction of the heater shall be such that the temperaturecof the nearest deck or bulkhead surface will not exceed 55°C. For test purposes, an ambient temperature of25°C shall be used.

(E). Control Switch. Cabin heaters shall be controlled by a single-pole switch.


9.2.2.6 Electric Cooking and Motor-Driven Commissary Equipment. Electric cooking and motor­ driven commissary equipment shall be provided with:

(A) Grab Rails. Grab rail where necessary for the safety of the crew

(B) Sea Rails on Ranges. Sea rails ort ranges With adjustable barriers to resist accidental pot movement.

(C) Grease or Fat Collector. Means for grease or fat collection to prevent spillage thereof onto the deck.

(D) Suitable Mounting and Anchorage. Suitable mounting and anchorage to prevent dislodgement by roll and/or pitch, whether arranged for fixed wiring or portable wiring.

(E) Disconnecting Means. Each equipment shall be provided with a means for disconnecting it from all circuit conductors within sight of the controlled equipment. The disconnecting means may be an integral part of the equipmellt, proYl:ded this device remains unaffected by the heat of the equipment.

(F) Watertigh(,�i,i.closure. The enclosures of motors and controls of motor-driven commissary equipment shall be either watertight or totally enclosed.

9.2.2.7 Electric Steel"ing System.

(A) Two Steering Systems. Where two steering gear motors and two separate and independent means of controlling the rudder from the pilothouse are installed, there shall be two steering systems, each consisting of a motor, control equipment, and steering gear feeder.

(B) Separate Installation. In general, these two steering systems shall be separately installed on a port and starboard basis.

(C) Interlocks. If a means of transfer is provided in the steering gear room so that either steering gear motor and associated control equipment can be connected to either of the two steering gear branch circuits, interlocks shall be provided to prevent both steering systems from being connected to the same branch circuit simultaneously.

(D) Short-Circuit Protection, Pilothouse steering control systems and any other electric means for controlling the rudder remote from the steering gear room shall be provided with short-circuit protection rated at 400% - 500% of the ampacity of the circuit.

(E) Pilot Light.Apilot light for each steering gear motor and each auxiliary motor controlling the rudder shall be provided at the propulsion control station, and other locations to indicate when the Il!Otors are energized.

(F) Automatic Indicator. The opening of steering gear branch-circuit breaker shall automatically be indicated at the propulsion control station by the sounding of an audible alann.

(G).Tank Vessels of 10 000 Gross Tonnage and Above. The steering gear systems of tankers/supertankers of 10000 gross tonnage or above that carry oil or hazardous materials in bulk, shall include the following:

(1) Two or more identical steering gear power units operable separately from the navigating bridge by remote control systems;

(2) An alternative power supply to the steering gear power units;

(3) Main steering gear control in the steering gear compartment;

(4) A rudder angle indicator on the navigating bridge and in the steering gear compartment;

(5) A means of automatically starting each steering gear power unit when power is restored after a p0wer failure;

(6) An· audible and visual alarm that is activated on the navigating bridge upon loss of power to a steering gear power unit or to the remote steering

gear control systems; and

(7) A means of communication between the navigating bridge, control stations and steering gear compartment.


9.2.2.8 Control of Ship.

(A) Passenger Ships and Cargo Ships. Ships shall have sufficient power for going astern to secure proper control of the ship in all normal circumstances.

(B) Passenger Ships Only. The ability of the machinery to reverse the direction of thrust of the propeller in sufficient time, under normal maneuvering conditions, and so to bring the ship to rest from maximum ahead service speed shall be demonstrated at the initial survey.


9.2.2.9 Maneuvering Controls.

(A) Indicating Lights. Where two or more control stations are provided, indicating lights shall be located at each control to indicate which station is in control.

(B) Alternative Control. Where bridge or deck control is employed, alternative control in the engine room shall be provided.

(C) Suitable Interlocks. Suitable interlocks, operating preferably by mechanical means, shall be provided to prevent damage to the power plant as a result of incorrect switching, such as the opening of switches or contactors not intended to be operated while carrying current.


9.2.2.10 External Electrical Supply.

(A)Shore Power Connection Box.Wherearrangements are made for the supply of electricity from a source on shore or elsewhere, like from a nearby ship or floating power plant and repair .dockyard, a connection box, commonly called a Shore Power Connection Box, shall be installed in a position suitable for the convenient reception of flexible cables from the external source and containing a circuit breaker or isolating switch and fuses and tenninal of ample size and suitable shape to facilitate a satisfactory connection. Suitable cables, permanently fixed, shall be provided, connecting the terminals to alinked switch and/or circuit breaker at;the main switchboard.

(B) Grounded Terminal. In addition a grounded terminal shall be provided for the reception of three­ phase external supplies with grounded neutrals.

(C) Indicator. The external connection shall be provided with an indicator at the main switchboard in order to show when the cables are energized.

(D) Polarity Checking. Means shall be provided for checking the polarity (for de) or the phase sequence (for three-phase ac) of the incoming supply.

(E) Full Information Notice. At the shore power connection box a notice shall be provided giving full information on the system of supply and the nonnal voltage (and frequency if ac) of the installation's system and the procedure for carrying out the connection.


9.2.2.11 Fire Detection and Extinguishing Systems.

(A) Power Supply. Where an electrically driven fire pump is supplied from the emergency generator the supply to such pump shall not pass through the main machinery spaces.

(B) Served by Two Circuits. Electrical equipment used in operating fire detecting equipment shall be served by two circuits, one fed from the main power source and one from an emergency power source. Such feeders shall be connected to an automatic change-over switch situated near to the fire detection panel.

(C) Additional Requirement for Passenger Ships. In addition to (a) and (b) above, the following requirements shall apply to passenger ships:

(1) Where automatic sprinkler systems are provided and electrical power is used for the operation of sea water pumps, air compressors and alarm fitted in conjunction with such system at least two sources of power shall be arranged, the main generator and the emergency source of power. One supply shall be taken from the switchboard by separate feeder reserved solely for this purpose. Such feeders shall be run to a change­ over switch situated near the sprinkler unit, and the switch shall be clearly labeled and no switch other than those at the switchboard is pennitted in these feeders.

(2) In passenger ships with aluminum superstructures where feeders from the emergency generator to the sprinkler unit passes through any space constituting a fire risk the cables shall be of fireproof type.


9.2.2.12 Remote Stops for Ventilating Fans and Pumps.

(A) Means for Stopping Ventilating Fans. Means shall be provided for stopping ventilating fans serving machinery spaces. These means shall be capable of being operated from outside such spaces in case of fire.

(B) Fitted with Remote Controls. Machinery driving

forced and induced draft fans, independently driven pumps delivering oil to main propulsion machinery for bearing lubrication and piston cooling, oil fuel transfer pumps, oil fuel unit pumps and other similar fuel pumps shallNbe fitted with remote controls situated outside the space concerned so that they may be stopped in the event of fire arising in the space in which they are located.

(C) For Passenger Ships Carrying More Than 36 Passengers. All power ventilation systems, except cargo and machinery space ventilation, which shall be in accordance with requirements of (a) and (b) above, shall be provided with master controls so that all fans may be stopped from either of two separate positions which shall be situated as far apart as practicable.

9.2.2.13 Discharge Protection.

(A) Means for Limiting Induced Voltage for Protection of Field Windings/Cables. For the protection of field windings and cables, means shall be provided for limiting the induced voltage when the field circuits are opened or, altematively,.the.induced voltage when the field circuits are opened shall be taken at the nominal design voltage.

(B) Means to Limit Induced Voltage at Busbars. Where excitation is obtained from the auxiliary busbars, means shall be provided to limit the voltage induced at the busbars when the auxiliary circuit breaker or the distribution circuit breaker opens.

(C) Shunt Resistors. Shunt resistors which are connected across the field circuit of synchronous propulsion motors, when they are functioning as asynchronous motors, shall be suitably insulated from the voltage induced when reversing, and shall be'amply rated to allow for inadvertent delay during the reversing operation.


9.2.2.14 Electrical Equipment for Use in Explosive Gas Atmospheres.

(A) Safe Type. Where electrical equipment is installed in areas where explosive gas atmospheres may be present, it shall be of a SAFE TYPE, certified for the gases/vapors involved.

(B) Types of Protection, Certified safe type equipment includes the following types of protection:

Intrinsically safe Ex "i"

Increased safety Ex "e"

Flameproof Ex "d"

Pressurized enclosure Ex "p"

(C) In Hazardous Zones. When "SAFE TYPE" equipment is permitted in hazardous zones or spaces

all switches, and protective devices are to intenupt all lines or phases and, where practicable, shall be located in a nonhazardous zone or space unless specifically pennitted othernise. Such equipment, switches and protective devices shall be suitably labeled for identification purposes.


9.2.2.15 Safety Devices.

(A) Means to Prevent Reversal of Direction of Rotation of DC Generator. Where separately driven direct-current generators are connected electrically in series, means shall be provided to prevent reversal of the direction of rotation of any of them on the failure of the prime mover.

(B) Means for Absorbing/Limiting Regenerated Energy. Where, on stopping or reversing the propeller, the regenerated energy transmitted by the propulsion motor is such as to cause a dangerous increase of speed in the prime mover, means shall be provided for suitably absorbing or limiting such energy.

(C) Means for Forcibly Opening of Contactors and Switches. Contactors and switches used for reversing the rotation of the propulsion motors shall be provided with means for forcibly opening them if they should inadvertently remain closed, and they shall be so interlocked as to prevent the circuits for "ahead" and "astern" being closed simultaneously.


9.2.2.16 General Alarm. In all passenger and cargo ships, and ferry boats, and oil offshore drilling rigs protection platfonns, and habitat unit, electrically operated alanns for summoning passengers and crews to muster stations shall be provided and shall be operable from the navigating bridge.


ARTICLE 9.3 -SYSTEMS OF SUPPLY AND DISTRIBUTION

9.3.1 General


9.3.1.1 Wiring Systems. The supply and distribution wiring installation on or inside watercraft shall be one or combination of the following:

(A) Parallel Systems with Constant Pressure,

(1) With Hull Return. In hull return systems, every conductor carrying the current from a circuit to the steel hull shall have the same cross- section as the corresponding insulated conductor. In de the negative pole of generators and of current consuming appliances shall be grounded in readily accessible places.


826

'

II"


a. DC two-wire.

b. AC single-phase, two-wire.

c. AC three-phase, three-wire.


ARTICLE 9.4 - GROUNDING SYSTEM

(B) AC Equipment. AC equipment shall operate satisfactorily under voltage fluctuation of plus 6% or minus 10% at rated frequency, and under frequency fluctuation of plus or minus 5% at the rated voltage.

d. AC four-wire with neutral grounded but without hull returns.

(2) Passenger Ships, Cargo Ships, and Tankers/ Supertankers {No Hull Return).

a. DC two-wire, insulated.

b. AC single-phase, two-wire, insulated.

c. AC three-phase, three-wire, insulated.

Systems voltages for both alternating current and direct current shall not exceed: (1) 500 V for cooking and heating equipment permanently connected to fixed wiring; (2) 250 V for lighting, heaters in cabins and public rooms, and other applications not mentioned above; and (3) 55 V for emergency systems.

(B) Series Systems with Constant Current. (Direct current only).

9.3.1.2 High Voltage System.

(A) System Voltage. System voltage shall not exceed:

(1) 7000 volts ac or 1500 volts de for electric propulsion equipment; and

(2) 7000 volts ac for large generators and ac power equipment.

(B) Voltage Supply and Primary Distribution. For high voltage supply and primary distribution, three­ phase, three-wire, neutral grounded is acceptable. If the primary distribution is extended to areas remote from the machinery space, isolating transformers or other means shall be provided to prevent ground fault current flowing through dangerous zones.

9.3.1.3 Low Voltage System.

(A) System Voltage. System voltage shall not exceed 55 volts.

(B)Wiring Installation. Low voltage wiring installation shall be provided for emergency general lighting and navigational aids, and general alarm systems.

9.3.1.4 Standard Frequency. A frequency of 60 hertz is recognized as standard for�11 alternating current systems.

9.3.1.5 Operation Under Voltage and Frequency Fluctuations.

(A) DC Equipment. DC equipment shall operate satisfactorily under voltage fluctuation of plus 6% or minus 10%.

(C) Contactor and Similar Equipment. Contactor and similar equipment shall not drop out at or above 85% of the rated voltage.

ARTICLE 9.4 - GROUNDING SYSTEM

9.4.1 General

9.4.1.1 Requirements.

(A) Grounding. No current-carrying parts of an insulated distribution system shall be grounded (refer to Section 2.50.2.7). However, components used for the suppression of radio interference may be connected between the insulated system and ground.

(B) Indication. Every insulated distribution system shall be provided with lamps or other means to indicate the state of insulation from ground.

(C) Protection. Current-carrying parts with voltage to ground shall be protected agsainst accidental contact.

(D) Detection. A ground detector device for insulated system shall be installed to continuously monitor the insulation level, particularly of circuits (other than intrinsically safe circuits) which pass through dangerous or hazardous zones or spaces or which are connected to apparatus installed in such zones or spaces. The device shall operate an alann in the event of abnormally low level of insulation.

(E) Metallic Riggings. All metallic riggings shall be grounded by flexible galvanized steel cables lashed to the rigging and securely fastened by solderless lug connectors to the metal hull.

9.4.2 Grounding Electrical Equipment

9.4.2.1 Portable Electrical Equipment. Metal frames of all portable lamps, tools and similar apparatus supplied as service or unit's equipment and rated in excess of 55 volts shall be grounded through a suitable conductor unless equivalent safety provisions are made such as by double insulation or by an isolating transformer.

9.4.2.2 Permanent Electrical Equipment. In general, the frames or casings of all permanently installed generators, motors, controllers, instruments, and similar equipment, for which the arrangement and method of installation does not assure positive grounding, shall be permanently grounded through separate conductor and protected against damage. Where outlets, switches and similar fittings are of nonmetallic construction,

grounding of all exposed metal parts shall be insured.


9.4.3 Grounded Neutral Systems


9.4,J,1 Grounding Resistor. When the grounded neutral system of generation and distribution is used, grounding shall be through a resistor. The resistor shall be such that ground-fault-current is limited to a value which is not greater than the full-load current of the largest generator on a switchboard section nor less than three times the minimum current required to operate any device against ground fault.


9.4.3.2 Harmonic Content, Generator neutrals may be connected in common, provided that the third hannonic content of the waveform of each generator does not exceed 5%.

9.4.3.3 Dual Voltage AC Distribution. For dual voltage, grounded neutral, ac distribution systems, an aID!Ileter shall be provided to indicate current flowing in the ground connection. Th� ammeter shall have a full scale range of 10 amperes. An ammeter switch of the spring return to ON (ammeter read) type shall be provided. Where the ammeter is located remote from the gfound connection and a current transformer is used, a suitable protective device shall be provided near the current transformer to prevent high voltage in the event of an open circuit. The ammeter and associated instrument shall be capable of sustaining without damage the maximum fault-current available.


9.4.3.4 Dual Voltage DC Distribution. For three-wire dual voltage, grounded neutral, de distribution systems, shall be solidly grounded at the generator switchboard with a zero-center ammeter in the ground connection. The zero-center ammeter shall have a full-scale reading of 150% of the ne�tral-current rating of the largest generator and shall be marked to indicate the polarity of grounds. The ground connection shall be made in such a manner that it will not prevent checking the insulation resistance of the generator to ground before the generator is connected to the bus. The grounded neutral conductor of a three-wire feeder shall be provided with a means for disconnecting and shall be so arranged th�t the grounded conductor cannot be opened without simultaneously opening the ungrounded conductors.


9.4.3.5 Connection to the Metal Hull. All grounding

�esistors shall be connected to the metal hull. [n order to ��minate possible interference with radio, radar and communication circuits, it is recommended that groun�ing resistors be bonded together on the hull

'

side of the resistors, and that the means of bonding be separate from that provided by the hull.

9.4.3.6 Switchboard Grounding. Where a switchboard is split into sections operated independently or where there are separate switchboards, a grounding resistor shall be provided for each section or for each switchboard. Means shall be provided to ensure that the ground connection is not removed when generators are isolated.

9.4.3.7 Emergency Switchboard. No direct ground connection shall be provided at the emergency switchboard. The neutral bus shall be solidly and permanently connected to the neutral bus of the main switchboard. No interrupting device shall be provided in the neutral conductor of the bus-tie feeder connecting the hvo switchboards.


9.4.3.8 Ampacity. The ampacity of the neutral conductor of a dual-voltage feeder shall be 100% of the ampacity of the ungrounded conductors.

9.4.4 Bonding Ground System

9.4.4.1Watercrafts with Fixed Electrical Installation. All watercrafts provided withfixed electrical installation shall be equipped with a bonding system to:

(A) Prevent stray current corros.ion by confining stray current leakage inside the hull.

(B) Provide a low resistance path to ground for voltages that may be considerably in excess of those for which the system is designed.


9.4.4.2 Ground Connection at One Point. On watercrafts with grounded electrical systems, the bonding ground system and the system ground connection shall be made at one point.


9.4.4.3 Independent System. The bonding ground system shall be independent of the electrical system ground conductors except at the comm.on ground point.


9.4.S Grounding Conductor


9.4.5.1 Material. Grounding conductor shall be copper or other�pproved material and shall be protected against damag_e aDd, where necessary, from electrolytic action.


9.4.5.2 Size. The size of grounding conductor shall be equal to the cross-section of the current-carrying conductor up to 1.4 mrn2. Above this figure they shall be equal to at least half*e cross-section.�f1the current­ carrying conductor with a minimum of 14 mrn2;

828

r

! ARTICLE 9.4 - GROUNDING SYSTEM

9.4.6 Ground Indicators/Detectors

9.4.6.1 Lamp Indicators.

(A) Power and Lighting Systems. Power and lighting system isolated from a watercraft's main power and lighting distribution by transfonners or motor-generator shall be provided with a means of detecting grounds. If lamps are used for ground detection, they shall have a rating of not more than 25 volts. Every isolated distribution system shall be provided with lamps or other means to indicate the state of insulation from ground.

(B) Excitation Circuits. Excitation circuits shall be provided with lamps, voltmeters or other means to indicate continuously the state of the insulation of the excitation circuits under running conditions.

9.4.6.2 Ground Leakage Detection.

(A) Main Propulsion Circuit. The main propulsion circuit shall be provided with means for detecting ground faults. For de equipment exceeding 500 volts and for all ac equipment, aural and visual alarms shall be automatically operated on the occurrence of a ground fault, but the operation of such devices is not to interrupt the power supply. Aswitch may be provided to switch off the aural device, but in such cases the visual alarm shall remain switched on to indicate that the aural device is switched off.

(B) Automatic Opening. If a ground connection is used for operating the detector arrangements, then in de systems the ground circuit shall be automatically opened in order to stop the circulation of fault current. In ac systems, the fault current shall be intenupted or limited to a safe value.

(C) Ground Leakage Devices. Ground leakage devices shall be arranged to function for all ground faults exceeding 5 amperes. In three-phase staHonnected ac generators and motors with neutral points grounded, the ground leakage device shall operate on the occurrence of a ground fault in the windings of the machine, provided that 5% of the coils at the neutral and of each phase may be left unprotected by the device. In high voltage ac systems, where the capacitive leakage current is high, consid�ration shall be given to increasing the figure to 5%.;

9.4.7 Grounding of Metal Coverings of Cables

9.4·.7.1 Metal Covering of Cables. Metal covering of cables shall be effectively grounded at-both ends of the :cable; except in final subcircuits -other than those installed in. hazardous zones and spaces. Grounding at the supply end only will be considered adequate. This

does not necessarily apply to instrumentation cables where single point grounding may be desirable for technical reasons.


9.4.7.2 Electrical Continuity. The electrical continuity of all metal coverings of cables throughout the length of the cable, particularly any joints and tappings, shall be ensured.


9.4.7.3 Lead-Sheathed Cables. The lead sheath of lead-sheathed cables shall not to be used as the sole means of grounding the noncurrent-carrying parts of equipment.


9.4.8 Ground Continuity


9.4.8.1 Ground Continuity. Means shall be provided for ascertaining that all ground continuity are effective and that the bonding and grounding of metallic conduit and/or sheathing of metallic conduit and/or sheathing of cables is effective.


9.4.9 Grounding of Metal Conduit System


9.4.9.1 Metal Conduit Systems. Metal conduit systems shall be growided and shall be mechanically and electrically continuous across joints. Individual short lengths of conduits need not be grounded.


9.4.10 Grounding Pole for Receptacle Outlets and Attachment Plugs


9.4.10.1 Receptacle Outlets. Receptacle outlets operating at 50 volts or more shall have a growiding pole.


9.4.10.2 Attachment Plugs. Attachment plugs for permanently fitted equipment operating at 50 volts or more shall have a grounding pole and grounding conductor in the portable cord to ground the noncurren.t­ carrying metal parts of the equipment.


9.4.11 Grounding oflnstrument Transformers


9.4.11.1 Secondary Winding. The secondary windings of instrument transformers shall be grounded.


ARTICLE 9.5 - LIGHTNING PROTECTION SYSTEM

9.5.1 General

9.5.1.1 Requirement. Lightning conductors shall be provided for the following watercrafts:

(A) Each wooden mast or topmast of all wooden, fiberglass, composite and steel ships;

(B) Steel ships having steel masts or topmasts need not be provided except tank vessels, tankers, tankships or supertankers;

(C) Mobile offshore oil drilling rig/production platfonn and habitat.


9.5.1.2 Construction.

(A) Wooden Masts or Topmasts. In wooden, fiberglass and composite watercrafts provided with wooden masts or topmasts, the lightning conductors shall be composed of continuous copper tape and/or rope, having a section not less than 100 mm2 which shall be riveted with copper rivets or fastened with copper clamps to a

suitable copper spike not less than 13 mm in diameter, projecting at least 150 mm above the top of the mast or topmast. Where tape is used the lower end of the tape

is to terminate at the point at which the shrouds leave the ma!lt or topmast, and shall be securely clamped to a copper rope of not less than 13 mm diameter. This copper rope shall be led down the shrouds and shall be securely clamped to a copper plat<: not less than 0.2 m2 exposed area, fixed well below the light waterline and attached to the ship's side in such a manner that it will be immersed under all conditions of heel.

(B).Steel Mast or Topmast. In wooden, fiberglass and composite watercrafts provided with steel masts or topmasts, each mast or topmast shrull be connected to a copper plate in accordance with (a) above, the copper

• rope being securely attached to and in good electrical contact with the mast or topmast at or above the point at which the shrouds leave the mast or topmast.

(C) Steel Ships. In steel ships provided with wooden masts or topmasts, the lightning conductors shall be composed of copper tape or rope tenninating in a spike, as set forth in (a) above. At the lower end this copper tape or rope shall be securely clamped to the nearest metal fonning part of the hull of the watercraft.

(D) Size or the Lightning Conductor. A lightning conductor shall run as straight as possible, and sharp bends in the conductor shall be avoided. All clamps shall be brass or copper, preferably of the serrated contact type, and efficiently locked. No connection shall be dependent on a soldered joint. The lightning conductor shall be composed of continuous flat copper straps of flexible copper cables having a sectional area not less than 100 mm2 and attached by means of clamps.

(E) Resistance or the Lightning Conductor. The resistance of the lightning conductor, measured between the mast head and the position on the copper plate or hull point to which the lightning conductor is grounded, is not to exceed 0.02 ohm.


9.5.1.3 Protection of Sailboats (Nonmetallic).

(A) Sailboats. Sailboats with metallic standing rigging shall be adequately protected that all riggings are grounded, so that the mast and rigging will serve as the protective mast, and shall comply with Section

9.5. l.2(B).

(B) Open Day Sailers. Open sailboats shall be adequately protected if any shroud and back stays, and any continuous metallic track on the mast and boom are grounded to a copper plate of 0.093 m2 exposed area or to a metal rudder or metal center keel.

(C) Cruising Sailboats. All stays and all sail tracks of cruising sailboats shall be grounded since it is assumed that persons will be in proximity of fore-stays as well as after-stays.


9.5.1.4 Protection of Small Watercrafts. Small watercrafts may be protected by means of a temporary lightning protective mast, which shall be erected when lightning conditions are observed in the distance.

Grounding provisions shall be made by means of flexible copper tape or rope of not less than 80 mm2 cross-sectional area to a copper plate of 0.093 m2 exposed area.


ARTICLE 9.6 - DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM PROTECTION (DISTRIBUTION AND CIRCUIT PROTECTION)


9.6.1 General


9.6.I.1 Watercraft's Structure. The watercraft's structure shall not be used as a normal current-carrying conductor for power, heating and lighting system.

FPN: Hull current which may arise from the following are not considered to contravene this requirement: (a) sacrificial anode protective systems and impressed current cathodic protection system for outer protection or for installations within the machinery space; (b) limited and locally grounded systems, such as starting systems of oil engines.


9.6.1.2 Current�Carrying Part Not to Be Grounded. No current-canying part of an insulated distribution system sba!l begrounded, other than through components used for the suppression of radio interference.

ARTICLE 9.6 - DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM PROTECTION (DISTRIBUTION AND CIRCUIT PROTECTION)

9.6.1.3 Hull Return. Hull return shall not be used in tankers/tankship/super-tankers, and for tank vessels for carnage of dangerous cargoes, and in passengers and cargo ships. [See Section 9.3.1.l(A)(Z)l


9.6.1.4 Short-Circuit Protection. Short-circuit protection shall be provided in each energized pole of a de system and in each phase of an ac system.


9.6.l.5 Overload Protection. Overload protection shall be provided in:

(A) Two-wire de or single-phase ac system - at least one line or phase

(B) Insulated three-phase ac system - at least thre� phases.

(C) Grounded three-phase ac system - all three phases.


'9.6.1.6 No Fuse, Non-linked Switch or Non-linked Circuit Breaker. No fuse, non-linked switch or non­ linked circuit breaker shall be inserted in a grounded conductor. Any switch or circuit breaker fitted shall operate simultaneously in the grounded conductor and the insulated conductors.


9.6.1.7 Main Distribution Circuit Protection. Isolation and protection of each main distribution circuit shall be ensured by a multi-pole circuit breaker or switch and fuses. The protective devices shall allow excess current to pass during the normal accelerating period of motors.


9.6.1.8 Motor Circuit Protection. Circuits which supply motors fitted with overload protection shall be provided with short-circuit protection only.


9.6.1.9 Lighting Circuit Protection. Lighting circuits shall be provided with overload and short-circuit protection.


9.6.1.10 Power Transformer Primary Circuit Protection. The primary circuits of power transfonner shall be protected against short-circuit by circuit breakers or fuses. When transformers are arranged to operate in parallel, means of isolation shall be provided on the secondary windings. Switches and circuit breakers shall be capable of withstanding surge current.


9.6.1.11 Instruments Protection. Protection shall be provided for voltmeters, voltage coils of measuring instruments, ground indicating devices and pilot lamps, together with their connecting leads.

9.6.1.12 Capacitor Circuit Protection. Where capacitors for suppression of radio interference are fitted to busbars, generators, or steering gear, fuses of appropriate size shall be connected in the capacitor circuit.


9.6.1.13 Power Circuits and Lighting Circuits. Power circuits and lighting circuits shall be supplied from a switchboard independently.


9.6.2 Diversity Factor


9.6.2.1 Application of Diversity Factor. Circuits supplying two or more final sub-circuits shall be rated in accordance with the total connected load subject, where justified, to the application of a diversity factor. Where spare ways are provided on a section or distribution board, an allowance for future increase of load shall be added to the total connected load before application of any diversity factor.


9.6.2.2 For Cable Sizing, and Rating of Switchgear and Fusegear. The diversity factor shall be applied to the calculation for size of cable and rating of switchgear and fusegear.


9.6.2.3 For Winches. For winches the diversity factor shall be calculated.


9.6.3 Through-Feed Arrangements


9.6.3.1 General. Where a feeder supplies more than one distribution board or panelboard, it may be continuous from the switchboard to the farthest panel or it may be served at any intermediate panel. If the busbars of any distribution board or panelboard carry "through" load, the size of the busbars shall be designed for the total current. The size offeeder conductors shall normally be uniform for the total length, but may be reduced at any intennediate distribution board or panelboard, provided that the smallest section of the feeder is protected by the overload device at the distribution switchboard.

9.6.4 Lighting Circuits


9.6.4.1 Rating. A final subcircuit of rating exceeding 15 A is not to supply more than one point. The number of lighting points supplied by a final subcircuit of rating 15 A or less shall not exceed:

IO for 24 55 volts circuits

14 for 110 - 130 volts circuits

18 for 220 - 250 volts circuits

Exception: In final subcircuits for cornice lighting, panel lighting and electric signs where lampholders are closely- grouped; the number of points supplied is unrestricted provided the maximum operating current in the subcircuit does not exceed 10 A.

9.6.4.2 In Machinery Spaces. Lighting for machinery spaces, control stations and work spaces shall be supplied from at least two final subcircuits and from the emer"gcncy system, in such a way that failure of any one of the circuits does not leave the space in darkness.

9.6.4.3 In Hazardous Areas. Lighting in hazardous areas, switches shall be of the double pole type and wherever practicable located in a nonhazardous area.

9.6.4.4 In Unattended Spaces. Lighting of unattended spaces such as cargo spaces shall be controlled by multi-pole linked switches situated outside such spaces. Provision shall be made for the complete isolation of these circuits and locking in the OFF position of the means of control.

9.6.4�5 In ·PUII!P Rooms. Pump rooms immediately adjoining an engine room or similar nondangerous space may be lighted permanently fitted glass lenses or ports fitted in the bulkheads or deck so arranged as to maintain integrity of the structure. The externally mounted lighUng_fixturc shall be so desi�ed that the gastight flanged post forms part of the fixture. The lighting fixtures and wiring shall be located in the nondangerous space, alternatively flame-proof lighting fitting shall be fitted. The fittings shall be arranged on at least two independent final branch circuit to permit light from one circuit to be retained while maintenance is carried out on the other.


9.6.5 Unbalanced Load.


9.6.5.1.Three-Wire DC Systems. Unbalanced loads betweeu ali 01.:.t�r conductor tli1..:. ;�:,,,., 1i.iddle wire at the switchboards, section boards and distribution boards is not to exceed IS¾ of the full load curtent as much as possible.


9.6.5.2 Three-Wire AC.Systems. Unbalanced loads on each phase at the switchboards, section boards and distri..bu•tion boa' rds i:s not.to exc.eed 15% of the full load current:�,mµc� as possi�le..


9.6.6 Branch_Circuits


9.6.6.1 Branch. Circuits. All branch circuits shall be protected at'panelboatd only and any re<iuction in conductor siz·eshall be protected.

9.6.7 Motor Circuits


9,6.7.1 Subcircuit. A separate final subcircuit shall be provided for every motor required for essential services and for nonessential services having a full load current rating of 6 amperes or more.


9.6.7.2 Ampacity. The motor circuit shall have an ampacity of not less than 100% of the motor full-load current rating.


9.6.7.3 Conductor Size. No motor circuit shall have conductors less than 2.0 mm2•


9.6.8 Essential Services


9.6.8.1 Essential Services. Essential services are those services, together with the power sources for supplying them, necessary for the propulsion and safety of the watercraft, such as the following:

(A) Air compressors for heavy oil engines;

(B) Air pumps;

(C) Ballast pumps;

(D) Bilge pumps;

(E) Circulating and cooling water pumps;

(F) Condenser circulating pumps;

(G) Extraction pumps;

(H) Fans for forced draft to boilers;

(1) Feed water pumps;

(J) Fire pumps;

(K) Fuel valve cooling pumps;

(L) Lubricating oil pumps;

(M)Main lighting system forthose partsof thewatercraft normally accessible to and used by personnel;

(N) Navigational aids where required;

(0) Navigational lights and special purpose lights where required;

(P) Oil fuel pumps and oil fuel burnings units;

(Q) Oil separators;

(R) Scavenge blowers;

(S) Steering gears;

(f) Ventilating fans for engine and boiler rooms; and

(U) Windlasses.

r

! ARTICLE 9.6 - DrSTRIBlITION SYSTEM PROTECTION (DISTRIBUTION AND CIRCUIT PROTECTION)

9.6.8.2 Duplication of Services. Essential services that are duplicated shall be served by individual circuits separated throughout their length as widely as is practicable and without the use of common feeders, protective devices or control circuits.


9.6.8.3 Excess Nonessential Load. Where generators are operated in parallel and essential machinery is electrically driven, arrangement shall be made to disconnect automatically the excess nonessential load when the generators are overloaded. If required, this load shedding may be carried out in one or more stages. Incargo ships, circuits for cargo refrigeration machinery shall be included in the last group to be disconnected.


9.6.9 Circuits in Vicinity of Magnetic Compass


9.6.9.1 Apparatus and Wiring Connection Precautions. Precautions shall be taken in connection with apparatus and wiring in the vicinity of the magnetic compass to prevent disturbance of the needle from external magnetic fields.


9.6.10 Watercraft's Service Power Circuits


9.6.10.1 Segregation of Vital Circuits. Power feeders supplying apparatus required for essential services shall not be used for supplying apparatus which shall be disconnected when the watercraft is underway unless the branch circuit for the latter are so arranged that they can be disconnected at panelboards without interfering with the safe operation and safety of the watercraft.


9.6.10.2 Independently Supplied Circuits. In general, separate feeders sball be run for such groups as engine room and fireroom auxiliaries, radio transmitters, arc searchlights and ventilation sets, and motors for cargo preservation and handling gears.


9.6.10.3 Power Feeders to Be Disconnected. Power feeders for cargo elevators, hoists, and winches, which shall be disconnected when the watercraft is underway, shall not be used to supply ventilation sets, drainage pump motors, or any apparatus required for handling the watercraft.


9.6.10.4 Drainage Pumps. Drainage pumps outside of engine and firerooms and galley appliances should be run from a common feeder.


9.6.10.5 Cargo Spaces. All lighting and power circuits tenninating in a cargo space shall be provided with multiple pole disconnect switches outside the space.

9.6.11 Distribution Circuits for Passenger Service


9.6.11.1 Arrangement. On watercraft for passenger service constructed with firescreen bulkheads fanning fire zones, distribution circuits shall be so arranged that fire in any main fire zone will not interfere with essential services in any other fire zone.

9.6.12 Ventilating Systems


9.6.12.1 Cargo-Ventilating Fans. Cargo-ventilating fans and those for ventilating accommodation spaces shall not be supplied from the same feeders. All electrical ventilation systems shall be provided with means for stopping the motors in case of fire or other emergency.


9.6.12.2 Cargo and Accommodation Ventilation Systems. Cargo and accommodation ventilation systems shall be provided with two emergency stop stations as follows:

(A) First Emergency Stop Station. One station located in the wheelhouse or fire control room or in an accessible position in the passageway leading t�, but outside of, the space ventilated.

(B) Second Emergency Stop Station. The second station shall be located as distant as practicable from the other, except that the ventilation circuit breakers at the main watercraft's service switchboard may be considered as the second station provided all are grouped together and are conspicuously marked IN CASE OF FIRE, TRIP TO STOP VENTILATION.


9.6.12.3 Closed Recirculation System. The requirements of Section 9.6.12.2 shall not apply to closed recirculation system, or to include close ventilation systems for a motor or generator, diffuser fans for refrigerated spaces, room circulating fans, or exhaust fans for private toilets.


9.6.12.4 Machinery Space Ventilating Systems. Machinery space ventilating systems shall have the controls located in the passageway leading to, but outside of such space.


9.6.12.5 Remote Emergency Stop Stations. The remote emergency stop stations shall be protected by enclosures withglass paneled doors on thefront of which shall be marked IN CASE OF FIRE, BREAK GLASS AND OPERATE SWITCH TO STOP VENTILATION.


9.6.12.6 Stop for Each Control Switch. Each control switch shall have the STOP position clearly identified

and shall be provided with a nameplate showing the system with which it is associated.


9.6.12.7 Undervoltage Protection Type. The remote control system shall be of the undervoltage protection type and so arranged that damage to the master switch or cable will automatically stop the fans.


9,6.13 Steering Gear


9.6.13.1 Electric and Electro-Hydraulic Steering Gears. Electric and electro-hydraulic steering gears shall be served by two circuits from the watercraft's service switchboard.


9.6.13.2 One Circuit from Emergency Switchboard. One of the two circuits should be taken from the emergency switchboard if the rating of the emergency generator is sufficient to supply the steering gear in addition to the emergency loads specified in Section 9.6.30.3.


9.6.13.3 Circuits. The circuits shall be separated throughout their length as widely as practicable.


9.6.13.4 Ampacity. Each circuit shall have adequate ampacity for supplying all motors and control equipment nonnally connected to it and which operate simultaneously.


9.6.14 Shore Connection


9.6.14.1 Installation of Connection Boxes. Where arrangements are made for the supply of electricity from a source on shore, a connection box shall be installed in a suitable position in the watercraft. In case where shore connection cable can be drawn into aswitchboard easily and put into service safely, the connection box may be omitted provided the protective devices and checking devices stipulated in Section 9.6.14.2 are installed in the switchboard.


9.6.14.2 Connection Boxes. The connection box shall contain terminals to facilitate a satisfactory connection and a circuit breaker or an isolating switch with fuses. Means shall be provided for checking the phase sequence (for three-phase ac) or the polarity (for de).

9.6.14,.3 Cables Between Connection Box and Switchboard. The cables between the connection box and switchboard shall be permanently fixed and a pilot lamp for source and a switcl). or.a circuit breaker shall be provided on the switchboard.

9.6.15 Emergency Systems

9.6.1S.1 Feeders.

{A) Watercraft with Fire-Screen Bulkheads Forming Fire Zones. For watercraft provided with fire-screen bulkheads forming fire zones, at least one emergency lighting feeder shall be provided to supply only the emergency lights between two adjacent main vertical fire zone bulkheads. The emergency lighting feeder shall be separated as widely as possible from the normal lighting feeders supplying the same space.

(B) Emergency Feeders. Emergency feeders shall emanate only from the emergency switchboard, which shall be located near the emergency source of supply. The switchboard shall be so arranged that the circuits may be energized from either watercraft's emergency or main plant. The feeder for this purpose from the main watercraft's supply shall be fitted with a breaker, switch or equivalent disconnecting device at the emergency panel.

(C) Emergency Cables. Emergency cables for power, lighting and control equipment located outside the machinery space shall be installed so as not to pass through the machinery space or casings to ensure their functioning in the event of fire or other casualty causing failure of the main electrical installation. In addition, these cables shall be kept clear of the bulkheads and decks forming the boundaries of machinery spaces and casmgs.

(D) Separate Emergency Lighting Feeders. On watercrafts fitted with an emergency power and lighting system, a separate emergency lighting feeders shall be provided for emergency lights located in, or controlled from the wheelhouse. A distribution panel for these lights with a fused switch or circuit breaker for each branch circuit shall be provided.

(E) Separate Emergency Feeder. A separate emergency feeder shall be provided for the navigation light indicator panel.

9.6.16 Navigation Lights

9.6.16.1 Final Subcircuits of Navigation Lights. Navigation lights shall be connected separately to a distribution board, commonly called "NAVIGATION LIGIITINDICATORPANEL",reservedforthispurpose only, and connected directly or through transformers to the main and/or emergency switchboards.

9.6.16.2 Control and Protection. Each navigation light shall be controlled and protected in each insulated pole by a switch and fuse or circuit-breaker mounted on the indicator board.

9.6.16.3 Regarded as an Extension to the Main Switchboard. Where the navigation indicator panel is situated in the midships house, the midships subswitchboard is regarded as an extension to the main switchboard provided that it is supplied from the main switchboard by two cables each capable of carrying full load.


9.6.16.4 Automatic Indicator. Each navigation light shall be provided with an automatic indicator giving aural and/or visual indication of failure of the light. If an aural device alone is fitted, it shall be connected to a primary or secondary battery. If a visual signal is used connected in series with the navigation light, means shall be provided to prevent extinction of the navigation light due to failure of the signal.

The requirements of this section do not apply to tugs, trawlers, fishing and similar small watercrafts.


9.6.16.5 Provision. Provision shall be made on the bridge for such navigation lights to be transferred to an alternative circuit.


9.6.17 Lighting Feeders


9.6.17.1 Watercraft for Passenger Service. On watercrafts for passenger service constructed with fire-screen bulkheads forming fire zones, the lighting distribution system shall be so arranged that fire in any main fire zone will not interfere with the lighting in any other main fire zone.


9.6.17.2 Requirements.

(A) Lighting Supply and Arrangement. In engine room, boiler room, large machinery spaces, large galleys, alleyways, stairways leading to boat-decks and public spaces; lighting shall be supplied from at least two circuits and shall he so arranged that failure of any one circuit will not leave these spaces in darkness. One of the circuits shall be emergency lighting circuit.

(B) Lighting Supply in Passageways, Public Spaces and Passenger Berthing Spaces. The supply to lights in passageways, public spaces and passenger berthing spaces accommodating more than 100 persons shall be divided between two or more branch circuits, one of which shall be the emergency circuit.

(C) Lighting for the Wheelhouse, Navigating Bridge and Chart Room. Lighting for the wheel house, navigating bridge and chart room shall be supplied from two or more circuits, one of which shall be the emergency circuit.

(D) Separate Circuits for Cargo Space Lighting. Separate circuits shall be provided for cargo space lighting. The distribution panel of these circuits shall be located outside of the cargo spaces. The fixed lighting fittings of cargo spaces shall be controlled by multipole linked switches situated outside these spaces. Provisions shall be made for the complete isolation of these circuits and locking in the OFF position of the switches or switch box.

9.6.17.3 Daylight Signaling Lamp Circuit. A separate branch circuit shall be provided for the daylight signaling lamp, which shall also be connected to the emergency source of power supply.

9.6.17.4 Feeder Circuit for Radio Transceiver. Feeder circuit for radio transceiver shall be in accordance with the requirements of Article 9.31.

9.6.17.5 Internal Communications Equipment Circuits. Feeder circuits of internal communications equipment shall be in accordance with the requirements for communications systems. (See Chapter 8, and Article 9.31)


9.6.17.6 Exit Lights. Exit lights shall be provided at each point. The word EXIT shall be in red letters not less than 50 mm high.


9.6.17.7 Survival Craft Floodlights.

(A) Lifeboat Floodlights. Lifeboat floodlights shall be mounted so that they can be quickly directed manually either to the launching gear or to the lifeboat alongside without the use of tools. The floodlights shall be directly connected to the supply circuit by means of heavy duty cord, type S or the equivalent, and no receptacle outlet shall be employed.

(B) Liferaft Floodlights. Watercraft equipped with liferaft (inflatable or other approved or listed types) shall have floodlights for illuminating the storage station and their launching gears, if any, and water into which the liferafts are launched.


9.6.17.8 Crew Spaces and Work Areas. All spaces where the crew are regularly employed or quartered, shall he adequately lighted. Berth lights shall be provided for each crew member, permanently mounted and wired without the use of portable cords. The lights shall be installed so that beddings will not interfere with their operation.


9.6.17.9 Washrooms, Toilet Rooms, Etc. Washrooms, toilets, hospitals and other rooms shall be properly lighted.

9.6.17.10 Electric Heaters.

(A) Installation and Construction. Electric heaters, if used, shall be fixed in position and be so constructed as to reduce fire risks to a minimum.

(B) Type Not Permitted. Electric heaters of the exposed-element type shall not be used

(C) Connection. Each beater shall be connected to a separate final subcircuit except that up to 10 small heaters of aggregate current rating not exceeding 15 amperes can be connected to a single final subcircuit.

9.6.17.11 Refrigerated Cargo-Space Circuits. It is recommended that separate feeders and visual tell-tales be installed for all refrigerated-cargo spaces. Fan and diffuser rooms serving sub-freezing compartments shall be provided with an alarm, or the equivalent, operable from within the space for the protection of personnel locked inside. Usually 'the alann is heard from the passageway leading to and from the galley.

9.6.17.12 Engine-Starting Battery Systems. Battery systems for engine-starting purposes shall be of the one-wire type and the ground lead shall be carried to the engine frame.

9.6.17.13 Fire-Alarm System. Alarm bells shall he producing distinctive and strong sounds and installed in accordance with the requirements of Article 9.31.

9,6.18 Branch Lighting Circuits

9.6.18.1 General. Branch lighting circuits shall be protecte� by overcurrent protective devices rated or set at not more than 30 amperes. For detail ryfer to Article 3.1.

9.6.19 Pilot Ladders


9.6.19.1 -Illumination. Means shall be provided to illuminate pilot ladders at night.


9.6.20 Call Bell Circuits


9.6.20.1 Call Bell Circuits. Call bell circuits shall be run in suitable tubing or molding, but when passing through crew's quarters or- work spaces where they are subject to mechanical injurythey shall be run in conduit.
