9.6.21 Oil Pump Rooms and Spaces Adjoh;ting Oil Tanks

9.6.21.1 Oil Pump Rooms and Spaces Adjoining Oil Tanks. Oil pump rooms and spaces immediately adjoining oil lariks shall be lighted by lamps wired entirely with ex'plcision-proof wiring or with lead­ covered annored cable run through gastight fittings

having stuffing glands at inlet and outlet. The lamps shall be enclosed in airtight glass globes protected by heavy wire guards with controlling switches located outside the pump room.

No portable lamps other than self-contained battery­ fed lamps of a listed type shall be used in spaces where vapor or gas may accumulate.


9.6.22 Motor of0.25 Hp or More and Apparatus of More Than 660 Volt-Amperes


9.6.22.1 Connection to Lighting Circuits Not Permitted. Motors larger than 0.25 Hp and apparatus consuming more than 660 volt-amperes other than incandescent lamps shall not be connected to lighting circuits unless specially approved.


9.6.23 Receptacle Outlets


9.6.23.1 Watertight Receptacle Outlets. Watertight receptacle outlets shall be provided for chain lockers, windlass, steering gear and deck machinery spaces, boiler manholes, boiler rooms, coal bunkers, engine rooms, shaft tunnel recesses, and refrigerating machinery.


9.6.23.2 Nonwatertight Receptacle Outlets. Nonwatertight receptacle outlets shall be used in baggage rooms, mail rooms, deck lockers, deck fan rooms, and similar occupancies and locations.


9.6.23.3 Number of Receptacle Outlets. A sufficient number of receptacle outlets shall be provided in the machinery spaces to permit lighting of any machine vital to the operation of the watercraft with a portable light having a cord 22 m long.

A sufficient number of receptacle outlets shall be provided in berth spaces to permit the use of electric razors, radios, computers, adding machine and electric typewriters, and other portable electric equipment or gadgets without using portable cords of excessive length.

FPN: Berth lights with cords are not permitted in passenger accommodationsand crew's quarters. Joints inflexible conductors are not permitted.


9.6.24 Lighting Fixtures


9.6.24.1 General Requirements.

(A) Permanent Watertight Lighting Fixtures. Perm!lilent watertight lighting fixtures shall be used outside and in forecastle, poop deck, mess spaces not

used as living quarter, cargo spaces, engine room, boiler room, fireroom, steering gear, winch, and windlass rooms, deck and auxiliary machinery spaces, oil pump and inert gas rooms. These fixtures and their fittings shall l?e of noncorrodible material rendered watertight by means of glass globes protected by substantial metal guards. Their circuits shall be completely wired. No ground wires shall be employed to carry load current.

(B) Open Arc Lamps. Open arc lamps shall not be used except for searchlight, cargo and survival floodlights, and motion picture projectors.

(C) Fixture Globes. Fixture globes shall be protected by guards except in living quarters, wheelhouse, gyro room, radio room, galley, and similar spaces where they are not subjected to mechanical damage.

(D) Incandescent Lamps Lighting Fixtures. The lamps of incandescent lighting fixtures located in propulsion machinery spaces, boiler and engine rooms, and other spaces where flammable liquids are piped under pressure shall be protected by glass globes, or by similar means that will prevent a liquid from impinging directly on the lamp when sprayed on the fixture from any direction.

(E) Construction/Installation. Fixtures shall be so constructed or installed, or equipped with shades and/or guards that combustible material will not be subjected to temperature in excess of 90°C.

(F) Not to Be Used as Connection Boxes. Fixtures shall not be used as connection boxes for circuits other than the branch circuit supplying the fixture, except for the following conditions:

It Condition 1: One or more lamps of a multilamp fixtures are supplied from an emergency lighting circuit

Condition 2: When the number of lamps of a fixture

exceeds the capacity of a single circuit.


9.6.24.2 Lighting Fixture Installation and Construction.

(A) Exposed to Weather. Fixtures installed in locations exposed to weather or in places reached by splashing water shall be of watertight construction.

(B) In Wet or Damp Locations. Fixtures installed in wet or damp locations shall be at least of the dripproof type approved for the purpose.

(C) Covered with Noncombustible Material. Any combustible bulkhead or ceiling finish exposed between the edge of a fixture canopy or pan and the outlet box sball be covered with noncombustible material.

(D) Outlet Cover. Each outlet, after completion of installation, shall be provided with a cover unless it is covered by means of a fixture canopy, lampholder, or similar device.

(E) Support. Fixtures, lampholders, and receptacle outlets shall be securely supported, except that they shall not be screwed to the hull directly.

(F) Pendant Fixtures. Pendant fixtures shall be suspended by, and supplied through, threaded rigid conduit stems.


9.6.25 Grounding of Lighting Equipment

9.6.25.1 To Be Grounded. Lighting equipment, including fixtures, shall be grounded.

9.6.25.2 Considered Grounded. Lighting equipment shall be considered as grounded when mechanically connected in a permanent and effcctive manner to the metal structure of the watercraft, the armor of annored cable, or a grounding connector.

9.6.26 Final Subcircuits

9.6.26.1 Motor Circuits. In general, a separate final subcircuit shall be provided for every motor for important use and for every motor of rating at 1 kW or more.

9.6.26.2 Final Subcircuits for Lighting.

(A) Lighting Fittings Supply. Lighting fittings shall be supplied by final subcircuits separate from those for heating and power. This requirement docs not apply to cabin fans and electrical appliances for domestic use.

(B) Final Subcircuit or Rating 15 Amperes or Less. The number of lighting points supplied by a final subcircuit of rating 15 amperes or less shall not to exceed:

(1) 10 for the circuits up to 50 volts;

(2) 14 for the circuits from 51 volts up to 130 volts; and

(3) 24 for the circuits from 131 volts up to 250 volts.

In case where the number of lighting points and total load current are invariable, more than the number of points specified above it should be connected to a final subcircuit, provided that the aggregate load current does not exceed 80% of the rating of protective device in the circuit.

(C) For Panel Lighting and Electric Signs. In a final subcircuits for panel lighting and electric signs, where lamps holders are closely grouped, the number of points supplied is unrestricted, provided that the maximum


operating current in the subcircuit does not exceed 10 9.6.27.4 Motor Branch Circuits. Overcurrent amperes. protection devices for motor branch circuits shall be in

(D) Heater Connection. Each heater shall be connected to a separate final subcircuit except that up to 10 small heaters of aggregate current rating not exceeding 15 amperes may be connected to a single final subcircuit.


9.6.26.3 Final Subcircuit of Rating Exceeding 15 Amperes. A final subcircuit of rating exceeding 15 amperes shall not supply more than one point as a rule.


9.6.26.4 Protection of Final Subcircuits. Buch insulated pole of final subcircuits shall be protected by a fuse or a circuit breaker.


9.6.27 Circuit Protection


9.6.27.1 General. All conductors shall be protected in accordance with Sections 9.6.27.2 and 9.6.27.3. Feeders and branch circuits for lighting, heating or watercraft's service power shall have each ungrounded conductor protected by a circuit breaker or fuse of suitable interrupting capacity. Circuit breakers shall be independent-arm or trip-free type. Circuit breakers may he equipped with time trips, instantaneous trips or trips consisting of both time overcurrent and instantaneous features.


9.6.27.2 System Protection. Dual�voltage systems having a grounded neutral shall not have fuses in the neutral conductor, but a circuit breaker which simultaneously opens all conductors may be installed when desired. In no case is the dual-voltage system to extend beyond the final panelboard. Circuits shall be so disposed that the load will be balanced within 15%.


9.6.27.3 Overcurrent Protection Devices. Fuse ratings and ratings (or settings, if adjustable) of time-delay trip elements of circuit breakers shall not exceed the rated current capacity of the conductor to be protected as listed in the tables of Part 4.30.14, except otherwise permitted for motor and transformer branch-circuit protection. If the standard ratings and settings of overcurrent devices do not correspond with the rating and setting allowed for conductors, the next higher standard rating and setting may be used, but not exceeding 150% of the allowable rated ampacity of the conductor. Except as otherwise permitted for motor and transformer branch­ circuit protection, adjustable-trip circuit breakers of the time-delay or instantaneous type shall be set to operate at not more than 150% of the rated ampacity of the conductor to be ,protected.

accordance with the following:

(A) Direct Current Motor Branch Circuits. The maximum fuse rating or the setting of the time-delay trip element shall be the standard rating or setting equal to or, if not in exact agreement, next above 150% ofthc full-load rating of the motor served.

(B) Alternating Current Motor Branch Circuits. The maximum fuse rating or setting of the trip element shall be the standard value equal to or, if not in exact agreement, next above the value stated below:



Type of Motor

Rating or Setting in

%Motor

Full-Load Current

Squirrel-cage and Synchronous


Full-voltage, Reactor-or Resistor-

250

Starting


Autotransformer Starting

200

Wound Rotor

150

The setting of magnetic instantaneous trips provided for short-circuit protection only, and responsive to transient inrush, shall be the standard value nearest to, but not less than 10 times full-load motor current.

(C) Steering Gear Motor Circuits. For any breaker protecting steering-gear motor branch circuits, the trip setting shall be in accordance with Section 9.6.30.2.

9.6.27.5 Transformer Circuits. Each power and lighting transformer feeder shall be protected by an overcurrent device rated or set at not more than 125% of rated primary current. When a transformer is provided with an overcurrent device in the secondary circuit rated or set at not more than 125% of rated secondary current, the feeder overcurrent device shall be rated or set at a value not to exceed 250% of rated primary current.

9.6.27.6 Motor Running Protection. Running protection shall be provided for all motors except such protection shall not be provided for steering gear motors. The running protection shall be set between 100 % and 125% of the motor rated current.

9.6.28 Protection of Watercraft's Service Generators

9.6.28.1 General. Generators of less than 25 kW not arranged for parallel operation shall be protected by fus.es.All generators of25 kW and over shall be protected by a trip-fre� air circuit breaker providing long-time overcurrent protection not exceeding 15% above either

the full-load rating of continuous-rated machines or the overload rating of special-rated machines. The shutting down of the prime mover shall cause the tripping of the service generator circuit breaker.

9.6.28.2 AC Generators. Alternating-current generator circuit breakers shall be provided with short-time delay trips, except that for generators with a capacity of less than 200 kW having prime movers such as diesel engines or gas turbines which operate independently of the electrical system, consideration will be given to elimination of the requirement for short-time delay trips if instantaneous and long time delay trips are provided. In addition, where three or more generators are arranged for parallel operation, instantaneous trips shall be installed and set at a value in excess of the maximwn short-circuit contribution of the individual generator. The instantaneous and short-time overcurrent trips shall be set at the lowest values of current and time which will coordinate with the trip setting of feeder circuit breakers.

9.6.28.3 DC Generators. Direct-current generator circuit breakers shall be provided with an instantaneous trip set below the generator maximum short-circuit current. This trip shall be set at the lowest value of current which will coordinate with the trip-settings of feeder circuit breakers supplied by the generator.

9.6.28.4 Protective Device Tripping. Selective tripping shall be provided between generator, bus tie, bus feeder and feeder protective devices to insure the proper coordination indicated in Sections 9.6.28.2 and

9.6.28.3. In circuits supplying vital services, selective tripping shall also be provided between feeder and branch circuit protective devices. Each protective device shall have interrupting rating not less than the maximum short-circuit current possible at the point of installation.

9.6.28.5 Generator Circuits for Parallel Operation. Direct-current generators arranged for parallel operation shall be provided with reverse-current circuit-breakers trips. Generator ammeter shunts shall be so located that the ammeters indicate total generator current. Alternating-current generators arranged for parallel operation shall be provided with reverse-power relays.

9.6.29 Three-Wire Dual-Voltage DC System

9.6.29.1 Three-Wire DC Generators. Separate circuit-breakers poles shall be provided_ for the positive, negative, neutral and also for the equalizer leads unless protection is provided by the main poles. When equalizer poles are provided for the three-wire generators, the overload trips shall he of the "algebraic"

type. No overload trip shall be provided for the neutral pole, but it shall operate simultaneously with the main poles. A neutral overcurrent relay and alarm system shall be provided and set to function at a current value equal to the neutral rating.


9.6.29.2 Neutral Grounding.

(A) Main Switchboard. The neutral of three-wire dual­ voltage direct-current systems shall be solidly grounded at the generator switchboard with a zero-center ammeter in the ground connection. The zero-center ammeter shall have a full-scale reading of 105% of the neutral­ current rating of the largest generator and shall be marked to indicate the polarity of grounds. The ground connection shall be made in such a manner that it will not prevent checking the insulation resistance of the generator to ground before the generator is connected to the bus. The neutrals of three-wire de emergency power systems shall be grounded at all times when they are supplied from the emergency generator or storage battery. The grounded neutral conductor of a three-wire feeder shall be provided with a means for disconnecting and shall be so arranged that the grounded conductor cannot be opened without simultaneously opening the ungrounded conductors.

(B) Emergency Switchboard. No direct ground connection shall be provided at the emergency switchboard. The neutral bus or busses shall be solidly and permanently connected to the neutral bus of the main switchboard. No interrupting device shall be provided in the neutral conductor of the bus-tie feeder connecting the two switchboards.


9.6.29.3 Size of Neutral Conductor. The ampacity of the neutral conductor of a dual-voltage feeder shall be 100% of the ampacity of the ungrounded conductors.


9.6.30 Steering-Gear Circuits


9.6.30.1 Feeders. Electric and electrohydraulic steering-gear shall be served by two circuits fed from the main switchboard. One of the circuits may pass through the emergency switchboard. Each circuit shall have adequate capacity to supply all motors, control systems and instrumentation which are normally connected to it and which operate simultaneously. If the transfer arrangements are provided in the steering­ gear room to permit either circuit to supply any motor or combination of motors, the capacity of each circuit shall be adequate for the most severe load condition. The circuits shall be separated throughout their length as widely as is practicable on a port and starboard basis.

9.6.30.2 Protection.

(A) Short Circuit Protection. Each steering-gear feeder shall be provided with short-circuit protection only which shall be located at the main or emergency switchboard.

(1) DC Motors. For direct-current motors the feeder circuit breaker shall be set to trip instantaneously at not less than 300% and not more than 375% of the rated full-load current of the steering-gear motor, except that the feeder circuit breaker on the emergency switchboard shall be set to trip at not less than 200%.

(2) AC Motors. For alternating-current motors the instantaneous trip setting of the feeder circuit breaker shall be 200% of the steady-state locked­ rotor current of one steering-gear motor plus all other loads that may be on this feeder.

(3) Fuses as Motor-Feeder Protection. The use of fuses instead of circuit breakers for steering­ gear motor-feeder short-circuit protection is not permitted.

(B) Undervoltage Release. Power unit motor controllers and other automatic motor controllers shall be fitted with undervoltage release.

9.6.30.3 Emergency Power Supply for Steering-Gear. Power from either the emergency source of power or from a source of power located within the steering-gear compartment shall be provided automatically within 45 seconds for all watercrafts having a required upper rudder stock diameter of 230 mm or more. This source of power shall be capable of moving the rudder from 15 degrees on one side to 15 degrees on the other side in not more than 60 seconds with the ship at summer draft while running at one half the maximwn speed ahead of 7 knots whichever is greater. In every vessel of 10 000 gross tonnage and upward, the capacity shall be sufficient for at least 30 minutes of continuous operation and in any other watercraft for at least 10 minutes of continuous operation.


9.6.30.4 Control, Instrumentation, and Alarms. Requirements for instrumentation and alarms are contained in Article 9.31.


9.6.31 AC Propulsion Circuits


'9.6.31.1 General. Alternating-current propulsion drcuits·shall be provided with a ground detector alarm or injjicatof.'If the iieutral is grounded for this purpose, it 'shall be through an artati:gement, which will limit the

current at full- to ground in the propulsion system. An unbalance relay shall be provided which is to open the generator and motor-field circuits upon the occurrence of an appreciable unbalanced fault.

9.6,32 DC Propulsion Circuits

9.6.32.1 Protection. Direct-current propulsion circuits shall not have fuses fitted, but each circuit shall be protected by overload relays to open the field circuits or by remote-controlled main-circuit interrupting devices. Provisions shall be made for closing circuit breakers promptly after opening.

9.6.33 Propulsion Excitation


9.6.33.1 Excitation Circuits. Excitation circuits shall not be fitted with overload circuit-interrupting devices except those intended to function in connection with the protection for the propulsion generator. In such cases the field circuit breaker shall be provided with a discharge resistor unless a permanent discharge resistor is provided.

9.6.33.2 Excitation Supply-Service Gener_ator Connection. Where the excitation supply is obtained from the ship's service generators, the connection shall be made to the generator side o"r the generator circuit breaker with the excitation supply passing through the overload current device of the breaker.


9.6.34 AC Three-Phase System


9.6.34.1 General. Three-phase, 3-wire ac circuits shall be protected by a triple-pole circuit breaker with three overload trips, or by a triple-pole switch with a fuse in each phase.

9.6.35 Electric Depth-Sounding Devices and Impressed Current Cathodic Protection


9.6.35.1 Electric Depth-Sounding Devices. Electric depth-sounding devices hermetically enclosed, located clear of the cargo tank bulkhead shall be provided with feeder cable installed in heavy gauge steel pipes with gastight joints up to the main deck.

9.6.35.2 Impressed Current Cathodic Protection. Where impressed current cathodic protection systems are fitted (for external hull protection only), and if it is essential for the cables to pass through cofferdams, the cables shall be installed in heavy gauge steel pipes with gastight joints up to the main deck. Corrosion-resistant

ARTICLE 9.7 - LIGHTTNG FITTINGS, HEATING APPLIANCES AND WIRING ACCESSORIES

conduits, providing adequate mechanical protection shall be used in compartments, which may be filled with sea water (e.g. pennanent ballast tanks).


ARTICLE 9.7---LIGHTlNG FITTINGS, HEATING APPLIANCES AND WIRING ACCESSORIES


9.7.1 General


9.7.1.1 Requirements. Lighting fittings, heating appliances and wiring accessories shall comply with the provision in other chapters of this Code, insofar as applicable, in addition with the requirements in this article.


9.7.2 Lighting Fittings


9.7.2.1 Construction and Location.

(A) Enclosure Composition. Enclosures shall be composed of metal, glass or synthetic resin having a sufficient degree of protection depending on their location. Synthetic resin enclosures, which support current-carrying parts, shall be flame-retardant.

(B) Terminal Box and the Leading-in Part of Cables. The terminal box and the leading-in part of cables shall be of construction suitable for marine cables. Consideration shall be given so that the insulation of cables will not be deteriorated at an early stage due to the temperature rise on terminals and other parts.

(C) Protection. Lighting fittings installed in machinery spaces or similar spaces which are exposed to the risk of mechanical damage shall be provided with suitable grilled metallic guards and glass globes to protect their lamps against such damage.


9.7.2.2 Fluorescent Lighting Fittings.

(A) Mounting. Reactors, capacitors and other auxiliaries shall not be mounted on surfaces, which are liable to be subjected to high temperatures.

(B) Protection Every capacitor of 0.5 microfarad or more shall be provided with a protective leak or other protective means which reduces the voltage of the capacitor to not more than 50 volts within one minute after disconnection from the supply source.

(C) Installation. Inductors and high reactance transformers shall be installed as close as practicable to the associated discharge lamps.

9.7.3 Heating Appliances

9.7.3.1 Construction and Location.

(A) Not Allowable. In principle, no bare heating element shall be used.

(B) Anti-corrosive Metal Sheath. Where the heating element is employed in liquid, it shall be protected by anti-corrosive metal sheath.

(C) Protection. The high temperature parts of electric heating appliances shall be so protected as to be kept from the risk of a combustible material coming in touch under normal working condition.

(D) Installation. Space heaters shall be installed in such a manner as to have no risk of dangerous heating of the deck or bulkhead or other surroundings.

9.7.3.2 Control Switches. Heating appliances shall be controlled by a fixed switch. Where a plug is used for the appliance, the fixed switch shall be placed in the immediate vicinity of the socket�outlet.

9.7.4 Wiring Accessories


9.7.4.1 Material.

(A) Metal or Flame-Retardant. Enclosures shall be of

metal or of flame-retardant material.

(B) Flame-Retardant and Non-Hygroscopic. The insulating material of energized parts shall be of flame� retardant and non-hygrqscopic material.


9.7.4.2 Temperature Rise. The temperature rise on energized parts shall not exceed 30°C.


9.7.4.3 Switches. Switches shall he capable of breaking and making safely a load current equal to 150% of their rated current at the rated voltage.


9.7.4.4 Plugs and Receptacle-Outlets.

(A) Switch Interlocked. Receptacle-outlets of rated current exceeding 15 amperes shall be provided with a switch so interlocked that the plug cannot be inserted or withdrawn when the switch is in the ON position.

(B) Design. Where distribution systems of different voltages are in use, the receptacle outlets and plugs shall be of such design that an incorrect connection cannot be made.

(C) Additional Contact for Grounding Conductor. Each receptacle-outlet and plug for 100 volts or more de and 55 volts or more ac shall be provided with an additional contact for grounding conductor, except those for double insulated appliances and for small

841

A

electrical appliances having no noncurrent-carrying metal parts for which grounding is required. Where it is necessary to ground the noncurrent-carrying parts of portable or transportable equipment, an effective means of grounding shall be provided at the receptacle outlet.

(D) Construction. Receptacle outlet and plugs shall be so constructed that they cannot be readily short­ circuited whether, the plug is in or out, and so that a pin of the plug cannot be made to ground either pole of the receptacle outlet.

(E) Effectively Shielded. On weather deck, galleys, laundries, machinery spaces and all wet situations, receptacle outlet and plugs sball be effectively shielded against rain and spray and shall be provided with means of maintaining quality after removal of the plug.

9.7.S Luminaires

9.7.S.1 General. Lighting which is essential for the safety and the working of the unit shall comply with the following requirements of Sections·9.7.2.2, 9.7.5.2, and 9.7.5.3.

9.7.S.2 Incandescent Lighting.

(A) Voltage Limit. The voltage of tungsten filament lampholders shall not exceed:

(1) Bayonet Fitting.

Normal B 22 250V Small (Single Contact) B 15s 130V Small (Double Contact) B 15d 130V

(2) Screw Fitting.


Goliath

E40

250V

Medium

E27

250V

Small

E 14

250V

Miniature

E 10

24V

(B) Wattage Limit. Lamps shall be in accordance with the following:

B 22 up to 200W E 27 up to 200 E 40 no limit

(C) Construction. Lampholders shall be constructed of flame-retarding and non-hygroscopic material. All metal parts shall be of robust construction. Goliath lampholders shall be provided with means for locking the lamp in the holder. The temperature of cable connections shall not exceed the maximum conductor temperatures permitted for the cable.

9.7.S.3 Discharge Lighting.

(A) Warning Notice. Where cold cathode luminous discharge lamps of normal operating voltage above 250 volts are used, a warning notice calling attention to the voltage shall be displayed at points of access to the lamps and where otherwise necessary.

ARTICLE 9.8 - SWITCHBOARDS, SECTION AND DISTRIBUTION BOARDS

9.8.1 General

9.8.1.1 Scope. The requirements in this article apply to the regulation and distribution of generated power through control equipment and protective devices of switchboards, section and distribution boards for compliance, in addition to the provisions of Article 4.8.


9.8.1.2 Controlling Equipment. Equipment contra Hing propulsion and various service equipment of the watercraft shall include the apparatus necessary for starting, stopping, reversing and controlling the speed of motors, together with essential safety devices. AU wearing parts of controllers shall be readily renewable,

9.8.1.3 Switchboard Installation and Location.

(A) In Dry Places. Switchboards shall be installed in dry places away from the vicinity of steam, water and oil pipes, and shall be accessible from the front and rear. Pipes shall not be installed directly above or infront of or behind switchboards. If such is unavoidable suitable protection shall be provided,

(B) Secured to Solid Foundations. Switchboards shall be secured to solid foundations, clear overhead deck beams by at least 100 mm, bulkheads by at least 460 mm, and shall be either self-supported or braced to the bulkhead or deck above. Means of bracing shall be flexible to allow deflection of the deck without buckling the control cell or assembly structure.


9.8.1.4 Space for Operation . and Maintenance. Switchboards shall be provided with a clear working space of at least 1000 mm at the front and a working space in the rear of not less than that given in Table

9.8.1.4. For switchboards which are enclosed at the rear and are fully serviceable from the front, clearance at the rear will not be required unless necessary for cooling. The working space shall permit operation and maintenance of disconnecting switches, switches, fuse and other part:s.

9.8.1.S Switchboard Mechanical Safety Protection. Where the energii:ed parts of switchboards are adjacent to a passageway, the following means shall be provided.

ARTICLE 9.8 - SWITCHBOARDS, SECTION AND DISTRIBUTION BOARDS

"May be reduced by not more than 1,u mm by use ot st1ttencrs and frame or by equipment on a single panel in the switchboard.

(A) Nonconducting Handrails and Guardrails. Nonconducting handrails at the front and nonconducting guardrails at the rear.

(B) Nonconducting Mats or Gratings. Nonconducting mats or gratings on deck flooring at the sides and rears of switchboards to protect tbe personnel from contact with energized parts to ground

(C) Drip-Covers. Drip-covers over top of switchboards when subject to damage by leaks or falling objects.

(D) Positioners and Stops. Hinged panels of dead front switchboards shall be provided with positioners and stops.

(E) Enclosure. The sides of switchboards shall be enclosed and the space in the rear made inaccessible to other than qualified persons.

(F) Cleared of Any Object. Rear of switchboards shall always be cleared of any object.


9,8.I.6 Protection oflnstrument Circuits.

(A) Overcurrent Protective Devices. Switchboard devices, such as pilot lights, ground detectors, lights for illumination, potential transformers, instruments and meters, shall be supplied by circuits protected by overcurrent devices.

(B) Not to Be Protected Against Overct1rrent. Circuits, the opening of which would create a hazard in the operation of the watercraft, shall not be protected against overcurrent. Such circuit usually includes electric propulsion control circuits, voltage regulator supply circuits, and service generator circuit breaker tripping control circuits.

(C) Grounded. Metal casings of instruments, relays, meters, and the secondary windings of instrument transformers located on switchboards shall be grounded.


9.8.2 Switchboard Construction

9.8.2.1 Enclosures and Assemblies. Switchboard enclosures and assemblies shall be constructed of steel or other suitable incombustible, moisture-resistant materials and reinforced as necessary to withstand the mechanical, electrical (magnetic) and thermal stresses likely to be encountered in service and shall be protected against corrosion. Insulating materials used in switchboard construction shall be flame retardant and moisture resistant.

9.8.2.2 Panels. Panels, should be made of impregnated ebony asbestos, laminated phenolic material or the equivalent." They should be made of metal if the mountings are properly insulated. The supporting framework for all panels shall be of rigid construction. No wood shall be used in the construction of switchboards, except that hardwork or non-conducting handrail shall be provided.

9.8.2.3 Dead Front. Switchboards of the metal clad type shall be used where voltage to ground or between poles exceeds 55 volts ac or de.

9.8.2.4 Short Circuit Rating. Circuit breakers and busbars shall be so mounted, braced and located so as to withstand the thermal effects and magnetic forces resulting from the maximum prospective short circuit current. Switchboard instruments, control, etc. shall be located with respect to circuit breakers so as to minimize the thermal effects due to short circuit currents.


9.8.2.5 Terminal Arrangements. All generators shall be protected against accidental contact, mechanical damage and where necessary, against dripping moisture by drip shields or dripproof enclosures. Where cables enter dripproof enclosures from the side or the top, they shall be provided with terminal tubes.


9.8.2.6 Mechanical Strength of Working Parts. All levers, handles, handwheels, interlocks and their connecting links, shafts and bearings for the operation of switches and contactors shall be of such proportion

that they will not be broken or distorted by manual operation.

9.8.2.7 Nameplates. Nameplates shall be provided for each piece of apparatus to indicate clearly its service. Nameplates for feeders and branch circuits shall include the circuit designation, description of the load served, and the rating or setting of the overcurrent protection devices.

9.8.2.8 Cable Entries. Cable entries of switchboards shall be so constructed that no water leakage is permitted into the switchboard along the cables.

9.8.2.9 Insulating Materials. Insulating materials used in the construction of switchboards shall be mechanically strong, flame-retardant and moisture­ resistant.

9.8.2.10 Switchboard Mountings. Busbars, circuit brceakers .and, other • electrical equipment of the switchboard shall be so :arranged·.thut ,the important electrical equipment. installed in, duplicat-ewill not become unusable simultaneously by a;single fault.

9.8.3 Switchboard Busbars and Contacts

9.8.3.1 Requirements.

(A) Generator Switchboard. Generator switchboard shall be provided for; each generator, and the switchboards-adjoining.each other shall be partitioned by,the walls.-of steel or flam�-retardant material. In case wh�re the tgtRI gutput of the m�In. gQnerntor!I iM oot

greater than 3 mflgawatts, the requirflmflnts may be

exempted. Wltere the total installed electrical power of the main generating sets is in excess of 3 000 kW, the main busbars shall be subdivided into at least two parts which. shall-be. connected .by removable links or other approved means. The connection of generating sets and any other duplicated equipment shall be eqµally divided between the partfl,

(B) Generator Busbars. Generator busbars shall be designed on a basis of maximum generator i'ati'ng.

(C) Ampacity. The ampacity of connection busbars for oiioh gemm1ting unit shn11not be less than thfl eontinuous rating of the generator plus 25% overload.

(D) Other Busbars and Busbar Connections. All other busbars and bushar connections shall be designed for afleasf 75% of the combined full-load rated currents of all apparatus they supply, plus not less than 50% of

the combined ratings of the spare switches or circuit breaker elements connected.to the busbar except ·that when· they supply one unit or any group of units in continuous operatidri they shall be designed for- full­

load.

9.8.3.2 Current Rating of Busbars. Busbars shall be proportioned to avoid temperature, which will affect the normal operation of electrical devices mounted on the board.

9;8.3.3 Arrangement.

(A) Busbars and Wiring. The arrangement of busbars and wiring on the back of switchboards shall be such that all lugs are readily accessible. Soldering lugs, where used, shall have a solder contact length of at least one and one-half times the diameter of the conductor.

(B) Nuts and Connection. All nuts and connections shall be fitted with locking devices to prevent loosening due to vibration.

9.8.3.4 Busbar Capacity. For more than one generator, with all generating capacity feeding through one section of the busbar, the capacity of the busbar shall be 125% of the largest generator plus 80% of the continuous rating of each added generator.

9.8.3.5 Conductivity. Busbars sp:a:11 b.e ofcopper having the conducti.vity of 97% or more. • •

9.8.3.6 Resistance , to Corrosion and Oxidation; Busbar connections shall be so made as to inhibit corrosion and oxidation;

9,8.3.7 Support. Busbars and busbar connection shall be so supported'"as to withstand the electromagnetic force resulted from short-circuiting.


9.8.3.8 Maximum Allowable Temperature; The maxim um allowable temperature of busbars, connecting conductors and their connections shall not exceed 90°C (at the maximum reference ambient temperature·of 45°C) when carrying full load current.


9.8.3,9 Clearances and Creepage Distances. Bare milin busbars in main rurd'emergency switchboards, but not including the conductors between the main busbars and the supply side of outgoing units, shall have minimum clearanc,:es (in air) and creepage di�tances· (across surfaces) in accordance with the Table 9.8.3.9

The values shall apply to clearances and creepage distances between energized parts as well as betweet;1 energized parts and exposed conductive parts, includ_i,ng grounding.

9.8.4 Equalizer for UC Generator ' !

than half of the rated full-load current of the generator.

9.8.4.2 Current Rating of Equalizer Busbars. The current rating of equalizer busbars shall not be less than half of the rated full-load current of the largest generator in the group.


9.8.5 Measuring Instruments for Switchboards

9.8.5.1 Watercraft Service DC Generator Panels. Watercraft service de generator panels shall at least be provided with the instruments given in Table 9.8.5.1.


9.8.5.2 Watercraft Service AC Generator Panels. Watercraft service ac generator panels shall at least be provided with the instruments given in Table 9.8.5.2.


9.8.6 Switchboard Equipment Requirements


9.8.6.1 ACB Contact Clearance from Watercraft Structure. Air circuit breaker contacts shall be kept at least 300 mm from watercraft structure unless insulation barriers are installed.


9.8.6.2 Clearance for Energized Front Switchboards. For energized front switchboards, the clearance between current-canying parts base channel shall not be less than 100 mm.

9.8.6.3 Voltage Regulator Element. Voltage regulator element shall be totally enclosed.

9.8.6.4 Ventilated and Isolated. Rheostats or other devices that may operate at high temperature shall be naturally ventilated and so isolated by barriers as to prevent transfer of excessive heat to adjacent devices.

9.8.6.5 Fuses Mounting. In general, all fuses shall be mounted so as to be readily renewable.

9.8.6.6 Wiring Protection. All wiring on the back of boards for voltmeter, pilot and ground lamps shall be protected by fuses.

9.8.7 Instrument Scales

9.8.7.1 Ammeter. The upper limit of the scales of every ammeter shall be approximately 130% of the nonnal rating of the circuit.

9.8.7.2 Voltmeter. The upper limit of the scales of every voltmeter shall be approximately 120% of the nonnal voltage of the circuit.

9.8.7.3 Ammeters and Wattmeters. Ammeters for use with de generators and wattmeters for use with ac generators, which may operate in parallel, shall be capable of indicating reverse current or reverse power up to 15% respectively.


9.8.8 Ground Indication


9.8.8.1 Ground Indication. Every insulateddistribution system shall be provided with lamps or other means to indicate the state of insulation, front ground. [See Section 9.4.6.l(A)].


9.8.9 Switchboard Wiring


9.8.9.1 Instrument and Control Wiring. Instrument and control wiring shall be of the stranded type not smaller than 1.25 mm� and shall have flame-retardant and moisture resistant insulation having the maximum pennissible conductor temperature not less than 75°C.


9.8.9.2 Hinged Panels Wiring. Wiring from hinged panels shall be of the extra flexible type.


9.8.9.3 Ducts and Straps Wiring. Ducts and straps for wiring shall be of the flame-retardant material.


9.8.9.4 Conductor of Different Circuits. Insulated· wires for control and instrument circuits shall not be bunched together with wires for main circuits, unless the rateii voltage and maximum perrmssible temperature of both wires are the same.

9.8.10 Protective Devices


9.8.10.1 General.

(A) Overcurrent Protection. Electrical installations of watercrafts shall be protected against accidental overcurrents including short.circuit. The protective devices shall be capable of continuously servicing other circuit as far as possible by breaking a fault circuit and eliminating damage to the system and hazard of fire.

(B) Short-Circuit Protection. Each pole and phase of all insulated circuits except neutral and equalizer circuits shall be provided with short-circuit protection.

(C) Overload Protection, All circuits liable to be overloaded shall be provided with overload protection as indicated below:

(1) Two-wire de or a single-phase ac system - at least one line or phase.

(2) Three-wire de system - both outer lines.

(3) Three-phase, three-wire system - each phase.

(4) Three-phase, four-wire system - each phase.

(D) Fuse, Non-linked Switch or Non-linked Circuit Breaker. Fuse, non-linked switch or non-linked circuit breaker shall not be inserted in•a grounded conductor and a neutral line.


9.8.10.2 Circuit Breakers and Fuses.

(A) Compliance with Chapters 2, 3, and 4. Circuit breakers and fuses shall comply with the requirements of Chapters 2, 3, and 4.

(B) Repairing and Replacing. Circuit breakers shall be such that repairing and replacing can be made withOut disconnecting from the busbar connections and switching off the power source. In case where isolation switch is provided additionally, the requirement should be exempted.

(C) Adjustable Current Setting and Time-delay Characteristics. Overcurrent relays of circuit breakers, except molded-case circuit breakers shall be capable of adjusting their current setting and time-delay characteristics.


9.8.10.3 Protection Against Overload.

(A) Thermal Capacity. The overcurrent trip characteristics of circuit breakers arid the fusing characteristic of fuses shall be chosen suitably talcing into consideration the thermal capacity of electrical equipment and cables to be protected thereby.

846 j

(B) Fuses Above 200 Amperes. Fuses above 200 A shal1 not be used for overload protection.


9.8.10.4 Protection Against Short-Circuit.

(A) Breaking Capacity. The breaking capacity of every protective device sball not be less than the maximum value of the short-circuit current which can fl.ow at the point of installation at the instant of contact separation.

(B) Not in Compliance. In case where the rated breaking capacity of short-circuit protection is not in compliance with the requirements of (a) above, fuses or circuit breakers having the breaking capacity not less the prospective short-circuit current shall be provided at the power source side of the foregoing short circuit protection. The generator breaker shall not be used for this purpose. The circuit breakers connected to the load side shall not be excessively damaged and shall be capable of further service in the following conditions:

Condition 1: When the short-circuit current 1s broken by the back-up circuit breaker or fuse.

Condition 2: When the circuit breaker connected to the load side is closed on the short-circuit current, while the back-up circuit breaker or fuse is broken.

(C) Making Capacity. The making capacity of every circuit breaker or switch intended to be capable of being closed, shall not be less than maximum value of short­ circuit current at the point of installation.

(D) Alternative. In the absence of precise data of rotating machine, the following short-circuit currents at the machine terminals shall be assumed. Where the loads are motors, the short-circuit current shall be the sum of short-circuit currents of generators and that of motors.

(1) DC System. Ten times the full load current for generators nonnally connected (including reserve unit). Six times the full load current for motors simultaneously in service.

(2) AC System, Ten times the full load current for generators normally connected (including reserve unit). Three times the full load current for motors simultaneously in service.


9.8.10.5 Protection of Generntors.

(A) Short-Circuit and Overcurrent Protection. Generators shall he protected against short-circuit and overcurrent by a multipole circuit breaker arranged to open simultaneously all insulated poles, or in the case of generators less than 50 kW not arranged to run in parallel, shall be protected by a multipole-link:ed switch

with fuse or a circuit breaker in each insulated pole. The overload protection shall be suitable to the thermal capacity of generators.

(B) DC Generators in Parallel Operntion. For de generators arranged to operate in parallel, in addition to the requirement in (a) above, an instantaneous reverse-current protection, operating at a fixed value of reverse-current within the limits of 2% to 15% of the rated current of generators, shall be provided. This requirement, however, docs not apply to the reverse­ current generated from load side, e.g. cargo winch motors, etc.

(C) AC Generators in Parallel Operation. For ac generators arranged to operate in pnrallel, in addition to the requirements in (a) above, a reverse-power protection, with time delay, selected and set within the limits of 2% to 15% of the full load to a value fixed in accordance with the characteristics of the prime mover, shall be provided.


9.8.10.6 Protection of Power and Lighting Transformers.

(A) Primary Cin:-.uits. The primary circuits of power and lighting transfonners shall be protected against short-circuit and overload by circuit breakers or fuses. (Refer to Section 9.10.1.5).

(B) Parallel Operation. When the transfonners :.rre arranged to operate in parallel, means of isolation shall be provided on the secondary circuits. Switches and circuit breakers shall be capable of withstanding surge currents.


9.8.10.7 Protection of Motors.

O In Accordance with Article 4.30. Protection of motors shall be in accordance with the provisions of Article 4.30.

(B) Motor of More Than 0.5 kW. Motors of rating exceeding 0.5 kW and all motors for essential (vital) use shall be provided individually against overload and

• short-circuit, except the motors for steering-gears.

(C) Delay Characteristic. The protective device shall have a delay characteristic to enable the motor to start.

(D) For Intermittent Service. For motors for intermittent service, the current setting and the.time delay shall be chosen in relation to the load factor of the motor.


9.8.10.8 Protection of Feeder Circuits.

(A) Circuit Breakers or Fuses. Supply' circuits to

section boards, distribution boards; grouped starters and the like shall be protected with circuit breakers or fuses.

In case where the fuses are used, the switches shall be provided at the power source side of the fuses.

(B) Supply Circuit with Overload Protection. Each ,supply circuit for the motor fitted with overload protection should be provided with short�circuit protection only.

(C) Protection Against Single Phasing. When fuses are used to protect polyphase ac motor circuits, consideration shall be given to protection against single phasing.

(D) Overvoltage Protective Devices, In case where condensers for phase advance are used, overvoltage protective devices shall be installed as required.


9.8.l0.9 Protection of Essential (Vital) Services. Where generators are opetated in parallel and essential (vital) machinery is electrically driven, arrangement shall be made to disconnect automatically the excess non-essential (non-vital) load when the generators are overloaded. If required, the preference tripping should be carried out in one or more stages.


9.8.10.10 Protection of ,Batteries. Batteries other than engine starting batteries shall be protected against overload and short-circuit with devices placed as near as practicable to the batteries. Emergency batteries supplying essential or emergency services may have short-circuit protection only.


9.8.10.11 Protection of Pilot Lamps and Control Circuibl.

(A) Fuses Fitted to Each lnsulating Pole. Protection shall be provided for voltmeters, voltage coils of measuring instruments, groWld indicating devices and pilot lamps with their connecting leads by means of fusesfitted to each insulating pole.A pilot lamp installed as an int�gral part -of another item of equipment need not be individually protected, provided that any damage of pilot lamp circuit does not cause failures on the supply to essential (vital) equipment. For other circuits, consideration shall be given to the Omission of fuses in circuits such as those of automatic voltage regulators where loss of voltage might have serious consequences.

(B). lnSulated Wires for Control and Instrument Circllits. Insulated wires for control and instrument circuits, directly led from busbars and generators mains shall be protecte4 by fuses at the nearest location to the connecting poiri't;. insulated wire� between the fuses and the conneding points Shall not he bunched together

with the wires for other circuits.


9.8.11 Section Board and Distribution Board


9.8.11.1 Location. Section board and distribution board shall be located in accessible positions and not in such spaces as bunkers, storerooms, cargo holds or compaiiments allotted alternately to passenger or cargo.


9.8.11.2 Protective Enclosures. Section board and distribution board shall have suitable protective enclosures that are mechanically strong. Where exposed to weather or other severe moisture conditions, they shall have protective enclosures of the approved non-combustible non-hygroscopic material made waterproof.


9.8.11.3 Switchboard-lype Distribution Panels. Distribution panels of the switchboard type, unless installedinmachinery spaces or in compartment assigned exclusively to electric equipment and accessible only to authorized personnel, shall be completely enclosed or protected against accidental contact and unauthorized operation.


9.8.11.4 Safety-Type Boards or Panels. If the method of operation demands the haridling of switches by unfamiliar personnel with electrical equipment, the section and distribution boards or panels shall be of the safety type.


9.8.11.5 Arrangement of Equipment. In case where the same section-board or distribution-board is used for the supply circuits having different voltages, all equipment shall be soarranged that the wires of different rated voltages can be laid without contacting each other within the boards. The section-board and distribution­ board or emergency distribution circuits are in principle to be provided independently.


9.8.11.6 Circuit-Disconnecting Devices. Panelboards for distribution to motor, appliance, lighting or other branch circuits, except the emergency bus-tie and general alarm circuits, shall be fitted with- multipole switches having a pole for each conductor. Overload protection shall be provided for each ungrounded conductor of feeders and each conductor of final branch circuits. Circuits shall be connected to the fuse end of switches and to the coil end of circuit breakers. The rating of the disconnecting devices shall be coordinated with the voltage and current requirements of the load.

ARTICLE 9.9 - SOURCES OF ELECTRICAL POWER

ARTICLE 9.9 - SOURCES OF ELECTRICAL (13) Main steering gear power unit compartment;



.,..

POWER


9.9.1 General


9.9.1.1 Propulsion Use. Tbe electrical power for the propulsion equipment should be derived from one or more propulsion generators whose exciters may either be direct-connected or independent.


9.9.1.2 Various Service Use. At least two mam generating sets of sufficient capacity to carry the necessary sea load essential for the navigation and safety of the watercraft and everybody on board, preservation of cargoes and provisions under normal condition, and continuity of services needed for the specific operation, with any one generator in rese1ve.


9.9.1.3 Emergency Use. Astorage battery and/or self­ contained generators, drivrn by a suitable prime mover with an independent fuel supply and with approved starting arrangements, the fuel used shall have a flashpoint of not less than 43°C.

FPN: For small watercra:fts in domestic trade, a shaft generator belt-driven from the shaft of the propulsion engine should be used.

(A) Emergency Loads. The following emergency loads shall be supplied with emergency power:

(1) Navigation lights;

(2) Daylight signaling lamp, if electricity operated from the main source of power;

(3) Machinery spaces and control stations (such as the fire control and recording stations);

(4) Generating set spaces (main, emergency, transitional or temporary, and storage battery room), and their control stations;

(5) Accommodation and service spaces;

(6) Alleyways, stairways, exits;

(7) Public spaces, such as mess hall, lounge spaces;

(8) Navigating bridge and chart rooms;

(9) Radio and communication rooms;

(10) Inert gas and oil pump room control stations (for tankers);

(11) General alarm including electrical signaling equipment for emergency calls;

(12) Engine order telegraph, if electrically operated from the main source of power;

(14) Watertight door gears, and indicating and sound signals;

(15) Every survival craft (lifcboat/lifecraft) stations and storage areas on deck and ovcrsides, also lighting of embarkation stations during the preparation for the process of launching;

(16) Refrigeration spaces and their alarm circuits;

(17) Sprinkler pump;

(18) Emergency fire/bilge pump(s); and

( 19) Fire detectors.


9.9.1.4 Transitional (Temporary) Use in Emergency. Two banks or more storage battery, with one bank in operation and the other banks in reserve, capable of carrying the emergency loads (as required for a particular class of watercraft) as specified in Section 9.9.1.3, are used, and shall operate even when the watercraft is inclined 22.5 degrees and the trim is 10 degrees.

9.9.1.5 Charger or Alternator. For watercrafts in domestic cargo carrier trade (passenger and ferry not included) with not more than 4 hours of navigation from point to point coastwise, charger or alternator shall be used to power the navigation and general lighting and bilging equipment.

9.9.1.6 Shore Power. During the dry docking of the watercraft, shore electrical power shall be supplied through the shore connection safety switch box of the watercraft, for general lighting, cooking and services for accommodation spaces, and for radio equipment.

(A) Installation of Connection Boxes. Where arrangements are made for the supply of electricity from a source on shore, a connection box shall be installed in a suitable position in the watercraft. In case where shore connection cables can be drawn into a switchboard easily and put into service safely, the connection box may be omitted provided the protective devices and checking devices stipulated in (b) below are equipped on the switchboard.

(B) Connection Boxes. The connection box shall contain terminals to facilitate a satisfactory connection and a circuit breaker or an isolating switch with fuses. Means shall be provided for checking the phase sequence (for three-phase ac) or the polarity (for de).

(C) Cables Between Connection Box and Switchboard. The cables between the connection box

and switchboard shall be permanently fixed and a pilot lamp for source ,md a switch or a circuit breaker shall be provided on the switchboard.


ARTICLE 9.10- GENERATORS

9.10.1 General

9.10.1.l Scope. Generators for propulsion and for various watercraft services shall comply with the minimum requirements in this article, in addition to the applicable provisions of Article 4.45.


9.10.1.2 Power Requirements. Electric power may be derived from two or more constant voltage propulsion generators usually provided in watercrafts propelled by electric power. Additional watercraft's service generators need not be fitted provided that with one propulsion generator out of service a speed of 7 knots or one-half of the design speed whichever is the lesser can be maintained.

(A) Propulsion. The power for each propulsion should be derived from a single generator.

(B) Service Generator. Watercraft using electricity for service power or light shall be provided with at least two electric generators for the watercraft service electrical demand.

(1) Number and Rating. The number and rating of the service generators shall be sufficient to ensure the operation when one of the generator set is out of service.

(2) Capacity. The capacity of the generator set or sets shall be sufficient to carry the necessary sea load essential for the safety of the watercraft, preservation of the cargo, propulsion power and minimum comfortable conditions of habitability under normal operation with any one generator set in service.

(C) Shaft Generator. A generator driven by a main propulsion unit (shaft generator) which is intended to operate at constant speed, e.g. a system where watercraft speed and direction are controlled only by varying propeller pitch, should be considered to be one of the required generators. Shaft generator installations which do not comply with this criteria should be fitted in addition to the above required generators provided that an alternative source of electrical power having a capacity sufficient for the loads necessary for propulsion and safety of the watercraft can be brought on line automatically within 45 seconds in case of the inability of the shaft generator to maintain voltage and frequency within prescribed limits for any reason.

(D) Sizing AC Generators. In selecting the capacity of an ac generating plant particular attention shall be given in the starting current forming part of the system. With one generator held in reserve as astandby, the remaining generator set operating in parallel, and initially carrying various load necessary for operating the watercraft shall have sufficient capacity with respect to the largest idle motor on the watercraft so that the motor can be started and the voltage drop occasioned by its starting current will not cause any already running motor to stall or control equipment to drop out of service.

(E) Independent Starting. Where only two main generators are provided, of which one depends on the functioning to the propulsion machine, dueconsideration shall be given so that the propulsion machine can be started independently of these two generators.

(F)Associated Load Management System. Where the electrical power system is designed with an associated load management system, the application of load in multiple steps of less than 50% of rated load shall be given special consideration.

9.10.1.3 Fault Current. Service generators shall be capable of withstanding the mechanical and thermal effects of fault current for the duration of any lime delay, which may be fitted ina tripping device for selective tripping.


9.10.1.4 Excitation.

(A) Service Generators and Emergency Generator. Excitation current for service and emergency generator shall be provided by attached rotating exciters or by static exciters deriving their source of power from the machine being excited.

(B) Propulsion Generators. Excitation current for propulsion generators shall be derived from attached rotating exciters, static exciters, excitation MG sets, or special purpose generating unit. Power for these exciters shall be derived from the machine being excited or from any watercraft service, emergency, or special purpose generating units.

(C) Propulsion Arrangements. Arrangements for propulsion generators shall be such that propulsion can be maintained in case of failure of an excitation system or failure of a power supply for an �xcitation system. Propulsion may be at reduced power under such conditions when two or more·propulsion generators are installed provided such reduced power is sufficient to provide for a speed of not less ttJ_an 7 knots or 0.5 of design speed, whichever is the lesser.

(D) AC and DC Exciters. Rotating exciters shall conform to all applicable requirements for generators.


r

ARTICLE 9.10 - GENERATORS

9.10.1.5 Shaft Current. Mearui shall be taken to prevent the ill effects of flow of current circulating between the shaft and the bearings.

9.10.1.6 Precaution to the Effect of Condensation of Moisture. Where there may be fear of deterioration of insulation due to condensation of moisture in the machine when idle, suitable means shall be provided to avoid it. Where steam-heating coils are installed for this purpose, there shall be no pipe joints inside the casing.

9.10.1.7 Moisture-Condensi1tion Prevention. When the weight of the generator, excluding the shaft, is over 455 kg, it shall be provided with means to prevent moisture condensation in the machine when idle. Where steam�heating coils are installed for this purpose, there shall be no pipe joints inside the casings.


9.10.2 Generator Construction


9.10.2.1 Frames and Pedestals. Magnet frames and pedestals may be separated but shall be secured to a common foundation.


9.10.2.2 Shafts. Shafting for generators shall meet the requirements for turbine rotors. Tube shafts, tailshafts, and coupling bolts shall meet the requirements for propulsion and line shaft bearing location.


9.10.2.3 Circulating Currents. Means shall be provided to prevent circulating currents from passing between the journals and the bearings, where the design and arrangement of the machine is such that damaging current may be expected.


9.10,2.4 Terminal Arrangements. All generator tenninals shall be protected against accidental contact, mechanical damage, and where necessary, against dripping moisture by drip shields or dripproof enclosures. Where cables enter dripproof enclosures from the side or the top, they shall be provided with terminal tu.bes.


9.10.2.S Namepl_ates.

(A) All Generators. All generators shall be fitted with nameplates of corrosion-resistant material marked with the following information:

(1) Manufacturer's type and frame designations;

(2) Output;

(3) Kind of rating;

(4) Temperature rise at rated load and design ambient temperature;

(S) Revolution per minute at rated load;

(6) Voltage;

(7) Amperes at rated load; and

(8) Type of winding (for de machines).

(B) AC Generators. ln addition to the applicable parts of the abovelist the following shall be included for ac generators:

(1) Number of phases;

(2) Frequency;

(3) Power factor;

(4) Exciter voltage; and

(5) Exciting current in amperes at rating.


9.10.2.6 Temperature Detectors. AC generators rated above 500 kVA shall be provided with means for obtaining the temperatures of the stationary windings. A minimum of one embedded temperature detector per phase shall be provided for this pUCJJ0Se on the hot end of the machine. The temperatures shall be indicated at a convenient location, preferably the generator control panel.


9.10.2.7 Propulsion Generators.

(A) Ventilation and Protection. Propulsion generators shall be enclosed ventilated or be provided with substantial wire or mesh screen to prevent personnel injury or entrance of foreign matters. Dampers shall be provided in ventilating air ducts except when recirculating systems are used.

(B) Fire-Extinguishing Systems. Propulsion generators which are enclosed or in which the air gap is not directly exposed shall be fitted with fire-extinguishing systems suitable for fires in electrical equipment. This will not be required where it can be established that the generator insulation is self-extinguishing.

(C) Air Coolers. Air cooling systems for propulsion generators shall be in accordance with requirement of lube oil pumps and sea suctions.


9.10.2.8 Insulation of Windings. Annature and field coils shall be treated to resist oil and water.


9.10.2.9 Lubrication. In general all generators shall be located with their shafts in a fore-and-aft direction on the watercraft and they must lubricate and operate satisfactorily in accordance with the inclination requirements.

Where it is not practicable to mount the generators with the armature shaft in the fore-and-aft direction, their lubrication will require special considerations.

Generators depending on forced lubrication, unless otherwise approved, shall be provided with means to shut down their prime movers automatically on failure of the lubricating system.

Provisions shall be provided to prevent oil or oil vapor from passing into the machine windings.

9.10.3 Voltage Regulation

9.10.3.1 Service Generator Sets. Service generator sets shall have voltage-regulation characteristics so that the watercraft's supply voltage will be maintained within plus or minus 4% at rated full load.

9.10.3.2 DC Generators. Where automatic voltage regulators are not supplied, the de generators shall be approximately flat-compounded except that, if the load fluctuation does not interfere with the operation of essential auxiliaries, shunt-wound generators without voltage reg14lators or stabilized shunt-wound machines may be used.

9.10.3.3 AC Generators.

(A) Voltage Regulators. In general a separate regulator shall be supplied for each ac generator. When it is intended that two or more generators will be operated in parallel, reactive-droop compensating means shall be provided to divide the reactive power properly between the generators. The regulator in conjunction with the exciter and the generator characteristics shall be capable of pcrfonning in accordance with conditions set forth in Section 9.10.3.1.

(B) Short Circuit Conditions. Under steady-state short�circuit c;:,nditions, the generator together with its excitation system shall be capable of maintaining a t;w1cu� \Ji not less than 3 times its rated full load current for a period of 2 seconds or of such magnitude and duration as required to properly actuate the associated electrical protective devices.

9.10.4 Parallel Operation

9.10.4.1 General. In general, when the installation is such that two or more generators are operated in parallel, the load on any generator shall not di.ffer more than plus or minus 15% of its rated kilowatt load.from i_ts proportionate share, based on the generator ratings, of the combined load for any steady state condition in the combined load between 20% and 100% of the sum of the rated loads of all

generators. The starting point for the detennination of the foregoing load-distribution requirements shall be at 75% load with each generator carrying its proportionate share.

9.10.4.2 AC Generators. For ac generating sets intended to operate in parallel, facilities shall be provided to adjust the governor sufficiently fine to permit an adjustment of load not exceeding 5% of the rated load at nonnal frequency.

9.10.4.3 DC Generators. DC generators which operate in parallel shall be provided with a switch which will trip the generator circuit break.er upon functioning of the overspeed device.

9.10.4.4 Turbine-Driven DC Generators Operating in Parallel. Where a turbine-driven de generator is arranged to run in parallel with other generators, a switch shall be fitted on each turbine emergency governor to open the generator circuit breakers when the emergency governor functions.


ARTICLE 9.11 - TRANSFORMERS


9.11.1 General


9.11.1.1 Scope. Transfonners rated at I kVA or more for single phase and at 5 kVA or more for 3-phasc shall comply with requirements in this article, in addition to the provisions of Article 4.50.


9.11.1.2 Number and Ratings of Transformers. The number and ratings of transformers for important use shall be sufficient to ensure the operation of essential services even when one of the transfonners is out of service.


9.11.1.3 Type of Cooling. Transfonners in accommodation spaces shall be of dry, naturally-cooled type.


9.11.1.4 Windings of Transformers.

(A) Moisture, Sea Atmosphere, and Oil Vapors Resistants. Transfonner winding shall be treated to resist moisture, sea atmosphere and oil vapors.

(B) Double Windings Transformers. Transfonners except those for motor starting shall be double wound.


9.11.1.5 Precautions Against Short-Circuit Current. Transformers shalJ be capable of withstanding, without damage, the thennal and mechanical effects of short­ circuit at the tenninals of any winding for two seconds.

ARTICLE 9.12 - STORAGE BATTERIES, BATTERY ROOMS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT

9.11.2 Temperature Rise

9.11.2.l Limit of Temperature Rise of Transformers. Temperature rise of transformers shall not exceed the values given in Table 9.11.2.l during continuous operation at the rated output, where, however, the ambient temperature is not more than 40"C, shall be increased by the difference from the values in the table.

9.11.3 Main Transformers


9.11.3.1 Main Transformers. Where transfonners or converters J an essential part of the propulsion or watercraft's service supply system, the system shall be arranged to ensure at least the same continuity of supply as required in Section 9.10.1.2 for generators.

9.11.4 Voltage Regulation


9.11.4.1 Voltage Regulation of Transformers. The voltage regulation of transformers shall not exceed the following values at full-load and 100% power factor:

(A) Single phase 5 kVA or more, and three-phase 15 kVA or more 2.5%

(B) Single phase less than 5 kVA, and three-phase less than 15 kVA 5.0%


ARTICLE 9.12 - STORAGE BATTERIES, BATTERY ROOMS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT


9.12.1 General


9.12.1.1 Scope, Storage batteries and their associated equipment for light and power, and for engine starting shall comply with the requirements in this article, in addition to the provisions of Article 4.80.


9.12.1.2 Construction. All batteries for used onboard watercrafts shall be of extra heavy duty for marine use with the cells so constructed and secured as to prevent spilling of the electrolyte due to the motion of the watercraft and to prevent emission of acid and alkaline spray.

9.12.2 Arrangement and Installation


9.12.2.1 Power and Lighting Batteries. Batteries for lighting and power shall be so arranged that the trays are accessible and with not less than 250 mm head room.

They shall be arranged in banks, series or parallel, such that while one bank is in use the other bank is being recharged for ready use when the fonner hank is discharge. Sometimes, a third bank is installed as standby.


9.12.2.2 Location.

(A) Near the Engine(s) Served. Cranking batteries shall be located as closely as possible to the engine(s) served.

(B) Not Exposed to Excessive Heat, Extreme Cold, Etc_ Batteries shall be located where they are not exposed to excessive heat, extreme cold, spray, steam or other conditions which might impair p�rfonnance or accelerate deterioration.

(C) Not in the Same Room. Alkaline batteries and lead acid batteries shall not be located in the same room. However, when placed in a compartment within the battery room, shall be effectively identified as to type and segregated far away as possible from each other.

(D) In Living Quarters, Work Spaces and Store, and Paint Rooms. Batteries shall not be placed in living quarters, work spaces and store, and paint rooms.


9.12.2.3 Large Batteries. Large batteries, those connected to a charging device with an output of more than 2 kW, shall be installed in a room assigned to the battery only, but may be installed in deck locker if such a room is not available. No equipment subject to sparking shall be installed in a battery room unless it is of the explosionproof type. The overload protective device required by Part 9.12.7 shall be placed in each battery conductor adjacent to but outside the room.

9.12.2.4 Moderate-Size Batteries. Batteries of moderate size, those connected to a charging device


Table 9,11.2.1 Limit of Temperature Rise of Transformers

(Based on ambient temperature 45°C)

to that insulation.

ARTICLE 9.12 - STORAGE BATTERIES, BATTERY ROOMS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT

with a power output of 0.2 kW up to and including 2 kW, may be installed in the battery room or may be installed in battery lockers or deck boxes in the emergency generator room, machinery space of other suitable location.


9.12.2.5 Small Batteries. Small batteries shall be installed in a battery box and may be arranged as desired.


9.12.3 Battery Trays and Types


9.12.3.1 Battery Trays. Trays for batteries shall be chocked with wood strips or equivalent to prevent movement and each tray shall be fitted with non­ absorbent insulating supports on the bottom and with similar space block at the side or with equivalent provision to secure air-circulationspace all around each tray.

9.12.3.2 Battery Types. Lead acid battery and alkaline battery when placed in the same battery compartment shall be effectively identified as to type and segregated.


9.12.4 Ventilation


9.12.4.1 Battery Rooms.

(A) Clearances. Battery rooms shall be ventilated in accordance with Section 4.80.l.9(A). Where batteries are arranged in two or more tiers, all shelves shall have spaces of not less than 50 mm, front and back, for air circulation.

(B) Natural Ventilation or Ventilating Fans. The ventilation of battery room may be conducted with either natural ventilation or ventilating fans.

(C) Natural Ventilation Allowed. Natural ventilation may be employed if ducts are I1U1 directly from the top of the battery room to the open air above.

(D) Mechanical Exhaust Ventilation, If natural ventilation is impracticable, mechanical exhaust ventilation shall be provided with fan intake at the top of the room. Fans shall be capable of completely changing the air in the battery room in not more than 2 minutes.

(E) Opening Near the Floor Surface. The battery room shall have openings near the floor surface, for effective air inlet.

(F) Construction. Ventilating fans shall be so constructed and to be of such a material as to render sparking impossible in the event of the impeller touching the fan casing.

(G) Location. Any fan motor associated with a duct used to exhaust the air from a battery space shall be placed outside the duct.

(JI) Ventilating Ducts. Ventilating ducts terminating at least 1250 mm above in the form of gooseneck or the equivalent shall be provided at the top of the battery boxes. Holes for air inlets shall be provided on at least the opposite sides of the box.


9.12.4.2 Battery Lockers. Battery lockers shall be ventilated, if practicable, similarly to battery rooms by a duct led from the top of the locker to the open air or to an exhaust ventilation duct, but the duct may terminate not less than 915 mm above the top of the locker in machinery spaces and similar well-ventilated compartments. Louvers or equivalent shall be provided near the bottom for entrance of air.


9.12.4.3 Deck Boxes. Deck boxes shall be provided with a duct from the top of the box, terminating at least 1220 mm above in a gooseneck, mushroom head or equivalent to prevent entrance of water. Holes for air inlet shall be provided on at least two opposite sides of the box. The entire deck box, including openings for ventilation, shall be watertight to prevent entrance of spray or ram.


9.12.4.4 Small Battery Boxes. Boxes for small batteries require no ventilation other than openings near the top to pennit escape of gas.

9.12.5 Electrical Installation in Battery Compartment


9.12.5.1 Lighting Fittings. Lighting fittings in battery room shall be flameproof type.


9.12.5.2 Electrical Equipment. Switches, fuses and other .electrical equipment liable to cause an arc shall not be installed in battery compartments.


9.12.5.3 Cables. Cables with the exception of those appertaining to the battery or the local lighting, shall not be installed in battery compartment except where installation in other locations is impracticable.

9.12.6 Battery Cables


9.12.6.1 Cables at the Battery Rooms. Where cables enter battery rooms, the holes shaH be bushed as req�red for watertight bulkheads. All connections within battery rooms shall be resistant to the electrolyte. Cables shall be sealed to resist the entrance of electrolyte by spray or creepage.
